{{Year nav topic5|2007|chess}} Events in [[chess]] during the year 2007:
==Events== (Top events in '''bold''')
===January=== *'''January 1''' – [[Veselin Topalov]] (Bulgaria) lost 30 [[Elo rating system|rating points]] but still tops the [[FIDE]] rating list at 2783. [[Viswanathan Anand]] (India) is second at 2779 and [[Vladimir Kramnik]] (Russia) is third at 2766. There is only one change in the players in the top eleven: [[Peter Svidler]] (Russia) dropped from number 4 to number 12 with [[Shakhriyar Mamedyarov]] (Azerbaijan) jumping from 12 to 4. At number 13 and rated 2727, [[Judit Polgár]] (Hungary) is the only woman in the top 100. Top juniors are [[Teimour Radjabov]] (Azerbaijan, number 11 at 2729), [[Magnus Carlsen]] (Norway, number 24 at 2690), and [[Sergey Karjakin]] (Ukraine, number 29 at 2678). [[Viktor Korchnoi]] (Switzerland) reenters the world top 100 at age 74, earning the 85th position with a rating of 2629.<ref name="twic634">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic634.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 634|date=1 January 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-21| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080217043306/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic634.html| archivedate= 17 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=3582|title=Topalov still tops the list, Anand four points behind|date=2 January 2007|periodical=ChessBase News|accessdate=2008-01-25}}</ref> *'''January 5''' – [[David Howell (chess player)|David Howell]], age 16 years 1 month, becomes the youngest British [[Grandmaster (chess)|Grandmaster]] ever. His second-place finish at the Rilton Cup in Stockholm with the score 7/9 gives him his third [[grandmaster norm]] and a rating of 2501.<ref>{{citation|last=Barden|first=Leonard|author-link=Leonard Barden|url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=3591|title=David Howell becomes a grandmaster at 16|periodical=ChessBase News|date=6 January 2007|accessdate=2008-01-25}}</ref><ref>{{citation|last=Barden|first=Leonard|author-link=Leonard Barden|url=http://sport.guardian.co.uk/chess/story/0,,1983850,00.html|title=Barden on Chess|date=6 January 2007|accessdate=2008-01-25|location=London|work=The Guardian}}</ref> *January 7 – 82nd [[Hastings International Chess Congress|Hastings International Congress]] 2006/7 won by GM [[Merab Gagunashvili]] (Georgia) and GM [[Valerij Neverov]] (Ukraine).<ref name="twic635">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic635.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 635|date=8 January 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-21| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080125162930/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic635.html| archivedate= 25 January 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *January 7 – 49th [[Reggio Emilia chess tournament|Reggio Emilia]] won by GM [[Viorel Iordachescu]] (Moldava).<ref name="twic635"/> *January 8 – 1st [[Association of Chess Professionals|ACP]] World Rapid Cup in [[Odessa]] won by [[Peter Leko]] (Hungary) over [[Vassily Ivanchuk]] (Ukraine) by 2½–1½ in the final.<ref name="twic635"/><ref>{{citation|last=Savinov|first=Misha|url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=3600|title=Peter Leko wins First ACP World Rapid Chess Cup|periodical=ChessBase News|date=9 January 2007|accessdate=2008-01-25| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080206122613/http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=3600| archivedate= 6 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *January 9 – 2006/7 [[Australian Chess Championship|Australian Open Championships]] in [[Canberra]] won by IM Zong-Yuan Zhao (Australia). GM [[Ian Rogers (chess player)|Ian Rogers]] (Australia) is 2nd, and [[Darryl Johansen]] (Australia) and GM [[Mark Bluvshtein]] (Canada) are 3rd=.<ref name="twic636"/> *January 11 – Moscow-London "Ice Chess" exhibition game is played by satellite link on large outdoor boards in Moscow and London with giant pieces [[ice sculpture|sculpted of ice]] in the shapes of local landmarks. [[Anatoly Karpov]] (Russia) and [[Nigel Short]] (England) serve as honorary captains with eight-year-old Russian and English [[chess prodigy|chess prodigies]] choosing the moves. The game is agreed [[draw (chess)|drawn]] after about an hour of play, with the pieces melting due to temperatures above freezing in both cities.<ref>{{citation|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/6252071.stm|title=Chess showdown ends in check melt|periodical=BBC News|date=11 January 2007|accessdate=2008-01-21}}</ref><ref>{{citation|last=Moss|first=Stephen|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk_news/story/0,,1988603,00.html|title=Time runs out for Russians in ice chess contest|periodical=[[Guardian Unlimited]]|date=January 12, 2007|accessdate=2008-01-25|location=London}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=3606|title=Ice Chess in balmy London and Moscow|periodical=ChessBase News|date=11 January 2007|accessdate=2008-01-21}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=3607|title=Ice Chess – a view from Russia|periodical=ChessBase News|date=12 January 2007|accessdate=2008-01-25}}</ref> *January 12 – [[Paul Keres]] Memorial Tournament in [[Tallinn]] "A Group" won by [[Georgy Timoshenko]] (Ukraine).<ref name="twic636">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic636.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 636|date=15 January 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-21| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080106121148/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic636.html| archivedate= 6 January 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *January 12 – 114th [[New Zealand Chess Championship|New Zealand Championship]] in [[Wanganui]] won by 16-year-old FM [[Puchen Wang]].<ref name="twic636"/> *January 15 – 32nd Ciudad de Sevilla won by GM [[Karel van der Weide]] (Netherlands) on [[tie-breaking in Swiss system tournaments|tie-break]] over GM [[Daniel Campora]] (Argentina).<ref name="twic637"/> *January 20 – [[Belarusian Chess Championship|Belarus Championship]] in [[Minsk]] won by GM [[Aleksej Aleksandrov]].<ref name="twic637">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic637.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 637|date=22 January 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-21| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080217043312/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic637.html| archivedate= 17 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *January 26 – 67th [[Armenian Chess Championship|Armenian Championship]] in [[Yerevan]] won by GM [[Karen Asrian]] in a playoff with GM [[Tigran Kotanjian]].<ref name="twic638"/> *January 27 – [[German Chess Championship|German Championship]] in [[Bad Koenigshofen]] won by GM [[Arkadij Naiditsch]] on tie-break over IM Rainer Buhmann.<ref name="twic638"/> *January 27 – [[Estonian Chess Championship|Estonian Championship]] in [[Tallinn]] won by GM Meelis Kanep after a playoff against GM Kaido Kulaots. WIM Tatyana Fomina won the women's title after a three-way playoff.<ref name="twic638"/> *'''January 28''' – [[Corus chess tournament|Wijk aan Zee]] is a three way tie between GM [[Levon Aronian]] (Armenia), [[Veselin Topalov]] (Bulgaria), and [[Teimour Radjabov]] (Azerbaijan).<ref name="twic638">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic638.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 638|date=29 January 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-21| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080212170019/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic638.html| archivedate= 12 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *January 31 – [[Cuban Chess Championship]] in [[Santa Clara, Cuba|Santa Clara]] won by [[Lazaro Bruzon]].<ref name="twic641">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic641.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 641|date=19 February 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-21| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080217042101/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic641.html| archivedate= 17 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
===February=== *February 4 – Moscow Open won by GM [[Evgeniy Najer]] on tie-break over GM [[Vasily Yemelin]] in a field of 245 players.<ref name="twic639">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic639.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 639|date=5 February 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-21| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080217043317/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic639.html| archivedate= 17 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *February 11 – Fenach [[Chilean Chess Championship|Chilean Championship]] in [[Santiago, Chile|Santiago]] won by [[Eduardo Arancibia (chess player)|Eduardo Arancibia]] on tie-break over IM Luis Rojas. (Chile has two chess federations. Fenach is the longer established of the two.)<ref name="twic642"/> *February 16 – [[Czech Chess Championship|Czech Championship]] in [[Prague]] won by GM [[Tomas Polak]].<ref name="twic642"/> *February 20 – [[Brazilian Chess Championship|Brazilian Women's Championship]] in [[Americana, São Paulo|Americana]] won by Suzana Chang.<ref name="twic642"/> *February 22 – 6th [[Aeroflot]] Open in Moscow won by GM [[Evgeny Alekseev (chess player)|Evgeny Alekseev]] in a field of 88, including 73 GMs, 11 IMs, 2 WGMs, and 1 WFM.<ref name="twic642">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic642.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 642|date=26 February 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-21| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080217042107/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic642.html| archivedate= 17 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *February 22 – [[Polish Chess Championship|Polish Championship]] in [[Opole]] won by GM [[Tomasz Markowski (chess player)|Tomasz Markowski]].<ref name="twic642"/> *February 25 – [[Romanian Chess Championship]] in [[Amara, Romania|Amara]] won by GM [[Constantin Lupulescu]].<ref name="twic642"/>
===March=== *March 10 – 125th Varsity Match between [[Cambridge University|Cambridge]] and [[Oxford University Chess Club|Oxford]] (the world's oldest regular chess event) is won by Cambridge in an upset.<ref name="twic644"/> *'''March 11''' – [[Linares chess tournament|Morelia/Linares]] won by GM [[Viswanathan Anand]] (India), with GM [[Magnus Carlsen]] (Norway) and GM [[Alexander Morozevich]] (Russia) 2nd=.<ref name="twic644">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic644.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 644|date=12 March 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-21| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080116103454/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic644.html| archivedate= 16 January 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *March 11 – Finnish Team Championship won for the first time by OpusCapita from [[Tampere]]. Matinkylä placed second for the fourth consecutive time.<ref name="twic644"/> *March 11 – Austrian Team Championship in [[Mattersburg]] won by Union Ansfelden.<ref name="twic644"/> *March 11 – Norwegian League championship in [[Oslo]] won by Oslo Schakselskap.<ref name="twic645">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic645.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 645|date=19 March 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-21| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080217042111/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic645.html| archivedate= 17 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *March 13 – 64th [[Georgian Chess Championship|Georgian Women's Championship]] in [[Tbilisi]] won by IM Lela Javakhishvili in a playoff against WGM Sopiko Khukhashvili.<ref name="twic645"/> *March 14 – [[Turkish Chess Championship|Turkish Championship]] in [[Ankara]] won by GM [[Suat Atalık]].<ref name="twic645"/> *March 17 – [[Serbian Chess Championship|Serbian Championship]] in [[Vršac]].<ref name="twic647"/> *March 18 – [[Polish Chess Championship|Polish Women's Championship]] in [[Barlinek]] won by IM [[Iweta Rajlich]].<ref name="twic646"/> *March 20 – 71st [[Bulgarian Chess Championship|Bulgarian Championship]] in [[Pernik]] won by GM [[Boris Chatalbashev]]. WGM [[Margarita Voiska]] won the women's championship.<ref name="twic646">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic646.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 646|date=26 March 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-21| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080217040719/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic646.html| archivedate= 17 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *March 24 – 8th Internet Chess Tournament "Ciudad de Dos Hermanas" ([[Internet Chess Club]]) won by [[Jorge Sammour-Hasbun]].<ref name="twic646"/> *March 24 – Belgian League won by CRELEL Liège. Also qualifying for the [[European Team Chess Championship|European Team Championships]] are Namur finishing second and Rochade finishing third.<ref name="twic647"/> *March 25 – 66th [[Georgian Chess Championship|Georgian Championship]] in [[Tbilisi]] won by GM [[Baadur Jobava]].<ref name="twic646"/> *'''March 29''' – 16th [[Melody Amber|Amber Blindfold and Rapid]] in [[Monaco]] won by GM [[Vladimir Kramnik]] (Russia) by two points, winning the blindfold event with 9/11 and finishing 2nd= in the [[fast chess|rapid]].<ref name="twic646"/> *March 30 – [[Kazakhstani Chess Championship|Kazakhstani Championship]] in [[Astana]] won by GM [[Darmen Sadvakasov]].<ref name="twic648"/>
===April=== *'''April 1''' – With an [[Elo rating system|Elo rating]] of 2786, GM [[Viswanathan Anand]] (India) becomes the sixth player to top the [[FIDE]] rating list since its inception in 1970. The April list drops former number one [[Veselin Topalov]] (Bulgaria) to number two at 2772. [[Vladimir Kramnik]] (Russia) remains at number three also at 2772. [[Alexander Morozevich]] (GM) rises to a career high fourth in the world at 2762. A rating of 2623 is required to make the top 100.<ref name="twic647">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic647.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 647|date=2 April 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-21| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080217042117/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic647.html| archivedate= 17 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://ratings.fide.com/toparc.phtml?cod=109|title=FIDE Top 100 Players April 2007|publisher=[[FIDE]]|accessdate=2007-01-21}}</ref> *April 1 – [[Chess Bundesliga|Bundesliga]] in [[Muelheim]] won by the OSC Baden Baden team featuring [[Viswanathan Anand]] (India), [[Peter Svidler]] (Russia), [[Alexei Shirov]] (Spain), and [[Magnus Carlsen]] (Norway). Hamburger SK finishes second and SG Köln Porz third.<ref name="twic647"/> *April 7 – 38th [[Mar del Plata chess tournaments|Mar del Plata Open]] won by GM [[Andrés Rodríguez (chess player)|Andres Rodríguez]] (Uruguay).<ref name="twic648">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic648.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 648|date=9 April 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-21| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080211234941/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic648.html| archivedate= 11 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *April 8 – Villa de Canada de Calatrava rapid g/25 won by GM [[Alexei Shirov]] (Spain) on progressive score over GM [[Daniel Fridman]] (Latvia), GM [[Ivan Sokolov (chess player)|Ivan Sokolov]] (Netherlands), and [[Boris Gelfand]] (Israel), all at 7½/9.<ref name="twic648"/> *April 8 – [[Danish Chess Championship|Danish Championship]] in [[Aalborg]] won by GM [[Sune Berg Hansen]].<ref name="twic648"/> *April 9 – 45th Doeberl Cup in [[Canberra]] won by GM [[Ian Rogers (chess player)|Ian Rogers]] (New South Wales) for the eleventh time.<ref name="twic649"/> *April 15 – "Chess Legends" [[Lajos Portisch]] (Hungary) and [[Boris Spassky]] (France) draw a six game rapid match in [[Heviz]], Hungary, both players winning one game and drawing four.<ref name="twic649"/> *April 15 – 33rd [[Bangladeshi Chess Championship|Bangladeshi Championship]] in [[Dhaka]] won by IM [[Abdulla Al Rakib]].<ref name="twic649"/> *April 16 – 8th [[European Individual Chess Championship|European Individual Championship]] in [[Dresden]] won by GM [[Vladislav Tkachiev]] (France) after playoff matches to break a several way tie for first. IM [[Tatiana Kosintseva]] (Russia) won the women's championship outright by two points.<ref name="twic649">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic649.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 649|date=16 April 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-21| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080217035241/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic649.html| archivedate= 17 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *April 22 – Italian Team Championship in [[Palermo]] won by Vimar Marostica for the seventh time.<ref name="twic650">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic650.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 650|date=23 April 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-21| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080102231104/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic650.html#5| archivedate= 2 January 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *April 24 – [[Moscow City Chess Championship|Moscow Championship]] won by GM [[Vladimir Belov (chess player)|Vladimir Belov]] on tie-break over GM [[Boris Grachev]].<ref name="twic651"/> *April 28 – Ukrainian Team Championship in [[Alushta]] won by Keystone.<ref name="twic651"/> *April 29 – [[Peter Leko]] – [[Vladimir Kramnik]] rapid match in [[Miskolc]] won by Kramnik 4½–3½.<ref name="twic651">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic651.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 651|date=30 April 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-21| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080217042127/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic651.html| archivedate= 17 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
===May=== *May 1 – Lugano Open finishes in a four-way tie for first between [[Robert Zelcic]], [[Joseph Gallagher]], [[Nenad Sulava]], and [[Michele Godena]].<ref name="twic653"/> *May 6 – World Cup holder [[Levon Aronian]] (Armenia) defeats World Champion [[Vladimir Kramnik]] (Russia) 4–2 in a six game rapid match held in [[Yerevan]].<ref name="twic652">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic652.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 652|date=7 May 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-21| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080217040725/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic652.html| archivedate= 17 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *May 6 – Chinese Zonal 3.5 in [[Shandong]] won by GM [[Bu Xiangzhi]].<ref name="twic659"/> *May 7 – [[4NCL]] won by Guildford-ADC 1 with a perfect record of 11/11 ahead of Guildford-ADC 2 at 10.<ref name="twic654">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic654.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 654|date=21 May 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-23| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071231062853/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic654.html| archivedate= 31 December 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *May 12 – Russian Team Championship won by Tomsk 400 ([[Alexander Morozevich]], [[Dmitry Jakovenko]], [[Sergey Karjakin]], [[Rustam Kasimdzhanov]], [[Ernesto Inarkiev]], [[Vladislav Tkachiev]], [[Victor Bologan]], and [[Pavel Smirnov]]) with a perfect 9/9 score.<ref name="twic653">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic653.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 653|date=14 May 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-23| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080217042132/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic653.html| archivedate= 17 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *May 12 – Baku Chess Festival won by GM [[Arkadij Naiditsch]] (Germany) over a field of 147. Naiditsch scores 7½/9 after a last round victory as Black over top seed GM [[Nigel Short]] (England).<ref name="twic653"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.chessclub.az/kubok2/index.htm|title=II International Chess Festival "President's Cup"|accessdate=2008-05-28| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080513040454/http://www.chessclub.az/kubok2/index.htm| archivedate= 13 May 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *May 13 – 74th [[Lithuanian Chess Championship|Lithuanian Championship]] in [[Šiauliai]] won by GM [[Šarūnas Šulskis]] with 8/11.<ref name="twic657">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic657.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 657|date=11 June 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-23| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080217042137/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic657.html| archivedate= 17 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *May 16 – Mitropa Cup in [[Szeged]] men's winner is France, women's winner is Hungary.<ref name="twic654"/> *'''May 17''' – 2006 [[Chess Oscar]] won by [[Vladimir Kramnik]] (Russia). [[Veselin Topalov]] (Hungary) and [[Viswanathan Anand]] (India) finished second and third.<ref name="twic654"/> *'''May 20''' – 3rd [[M-Tel Masters]] in [[Sofia]] won by GM [[Veselin Topalov]] (Bulgaria), his third consecutive victory in the event.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.mtelmasters.com/en/results.html |title=Results & Games<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=2008-01-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080315223844/http://www.mtelmasters.com/en/results.html |archive-date=2008-03-15 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> *May 21 – 16th Croatian Team Cup in [[Šibenik]] won by Lapor-Mladost, Zagreb (GM [[Zdenko Kozul]], GM [[Adrian Mikhalchishin]], GM [[Krunoslav Hulak]], GM [[Georg Mohr (chess player)|Georg Mohr]]).<ref name="twic655"/> *May 23 – [[U.S. Chess Championship|U.S. Championship]] in [[Stillwater, Oklahoma|Stillwater]] won by GM [[Alexander Shabalov]].<ref name="twic655"/> *May 23 – [[Uzbekistani Chess Championship|Uzbek Championship]] in [[Tashkent]] finished in a three-way tie for first at 9½/13 between IM [[Vladimir Egin]], IM [[Anton Filippov]], and GM [[Timur Gareev]].<ref name="twic659"/> *May 27 – [[World Chess Championship 2007|2007 Candidates]] round one matches begin.<ref name="twic656"/> *May 27 – 50th Serbia Team Cup in [[Mataruška Banja]] won by VSK Sveti Nikolaj.<ref name="twic655"/> *May 28 – 37th Bosna in [[Sarajevo]] six-player category 17 double [[round-robin tournament|round-robin]] top section won by [[Sergei Movsesian]].<ref name="twic655">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic655.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 655|date=28 May 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-23| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080102150434/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic655.html| archivedate= 2 January 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *May 29 – 42nd Capablanca Memorial in [[Havana]] elite section (ten GM single [[round-robin tournament|round-robin]], category 15) won by GM [[Vassily Ivanchuk]] (Ukraine) 7½/10, two points ahead of the field. *May 30 – 1st World Women's Team Championship in [[Ekaterinburg]] won by China with 17 points, ahead of Russia at 15 and [[Armenia]] at 14. Teams from ten national Federations participated.<ref name="twic656"/><ref>{{citation|last=Mirzoeva|first=Elmira|author-link=Elmira Mirzoeva|url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=3875|title=First World Women's Team Chess Championship 2007, Russia|date=22 May 2007|periodical=ChessBase News|accessdate=2008-01-24| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080204203326/http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=3875| archivedate= 4 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
===June=== *'''June 3''' – [[World Chess Championship 2007|2007 Candidates Matches]], final games of round one played. [[Levon Aronian]] (Armenia), [[Peter Leko]] (Hungary), [[Sergei Rublevsky]] (Russia), [[Boris Gelfand]] (Israel), [[Gata Kamsky]] (USA), [[Alexander Grischuk]] (Russia), [[Evgeny Bareev]] (Russia), and [[Alexei Shirov]] (Spain) advance.<ref name="twic656">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic656.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 656|date=4 June 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-23| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080112132252/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic656.html#6| archivedate= 12 January 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *June 3 – French Team Championship in [[Clichy, Hauts-de-Seine|Clichy]] won by Clichy over Cannes and Paris Chess 15. *June 8 – [[Leningrad City Chess Championship|St Petersburg Championship]] won by GM [[Marat Makarov]] on tie-break over IM Pavel Anisimov and Maxim Matlakov all at 6½/11.<ref name="twic657"/> *June 10 – 7th [[European Senior Chess Championship|European Individual Senior Championship]] in [[Hockenheim]] overall (men's) winner GM [[Nukhim Rashkovsky]] (Russia) on tie-break over IM Algiman Butnorius (Lithuania) both with 7½/9, women's winner [[Elena Fatalibekova]] (Russia).<ref name="twic658"/> *June 10 – Bosnian Team Championships won by SK Zeljeznièar, Sarajevo ([[Robert Ruck]], [[Zoltán Ribli]] etc.) over the favorites SK Bosna, Sarajevo ([[Zoltán Almási]], [[Ivan Sokolov (chess player)|Ivan Sokolov]], [[Nigel Short]], [[Sergei Movsesian]], [[Borki Predojević]], [[Suat Atalık]] etc.).<ref name="twic657"/> *June 10 – [[Uruguayan Chess Championship|Uruguayan Championship]] at [[Montevideo]] won by IM [[Bernardo Roselli Mailhe]] for the 12th time on tie-break over FM [[Manuel Larrea]].<ref name="twic659"/> *June 11 – National Open in [[Las Vegas Strip|Las Vegas]] won by GM [[Hikaru Nakamura]] (USA) with 5½/6. GM [[Viktor Korchnoi]] (Switzerland) is part of a six-way tie for second at 5.<ref name="twic657"/> *'''June 13''' – [[World Chess Championship 2007|2007 Candidates]] final games of round 2 played. [[Levon Aronian]] (Armenia), [[Peter Leko]] (Hungary), [[Alexander Grischuk]] (Russia), and [[Boris Gelfand]] (Israel) advance, qualifying for the 2007 World Championship tournament in Mexico City in September.<ref name="twic658">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic658.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 658|date=18 June 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-24| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080131175944/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic658.html| archivedate= 31 January 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *June 18 – 5th [[World Computer Chess Championship|World Computer Championship]] in [[Amsterdam]] won by [[Rybka]].<ref name="twic658"/> *June 20 – [[Colombian Chess Championship|Colombian Championship]] in [[Cartagena de Indias]] won by IM [[Alder Escobar Forero]], the women's event won by [[Martha Mateus]].<ref name="twic662"/> *June 24 – 3rd European Union Individual Championship in [[Arvier]] won by GM [[Nikola Sedlak]] (Serbia) on tie-break over GM [[Michele Godena]] (Italy), both scoring 8/10 in a field of 110.<ref name="twic659">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic659.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 659|date=25 June 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-24| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080217040734/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic659.html| archivedate= 17 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *June 28 – [[Dutch Chess Championship|Dutch Championship]] in [[Hilversum]] won by GM [[Sergei Tiviakov]] in a rapid playoff over GM [[Daniel Stellwagen]] after both scored 8/11. GM [[Peng Zhaoqin]] won the women's title with 8/9.<ref name="twic660"/> *June 30 – Aerosvit tournament in [[Foros, Ukraine|Foros]] (12 GMs, category 18) won by GM [[Vassily Ivanchuk]] (Ukraine) with 7½/11. GM [[Sergey Karjakin]] (Ukraine) placed second at 7.<ref name="twic660"/>
===July=== *'''July 1''' – The top three players on the [[FIDE]] [[Elo rating system|rating list]] remain the same: [[Viswanathan Anand]] (India), [[Veselin Topalov]] (Bulgaria), and [[Vladimir Kramnik]]. [[Vassily Ivanchuk]] gains 33 points to move up to number 4 from number 12. A rating of 2624 is required to make the top 100.<ref name="twic660"/> *'''July 1''' – [[Dortmund Sparkassen Chess Meeting|Dortmund Sparkassen]] won by GM [[Vladimir Kramnik]] (Russia). Kramnik scored 5/7, a full point ahead of the field of eight GMs in this category 20 single round-robin. This is Kramnik's eight victory in this event since 1995.<ref name="twic660">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic660.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 660|date=2 July 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-24| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080107163728/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic660.html| archivedate= 7 January 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *July 8 – [[Belgian Chess Championship|Belgian Championship]] in [[Namur (city)|Namur]] won by GM [[Alexandre Dgebuadze]] with 6½/9.<ref name="twic661"/> *July 8 – [[Irish Chess Championship|Irish Championship]] in [[Dublin]] won by IM Brian Kelly and FM Stephen Brady with 6½/9 finishing as part of a four way tie for 3rd–6th. The field of 52 included several foreign players who were not eligible for the title, including 4 GMs.<ref name="twic661"/> *July 8 – GM [[Ian Rogers (chess player)|Ian Rogers]] retires from competitive chess after winning the Lidums Checkmate Open. He had been the top Australian player for more than twenty years.<ref name="twic664"/> *July 9 – 20th Ciudad de Léon rapid tournament won by GM [[Viswanathan Anand]] (India), beating GM [[Veselin Topalov]] 3–1 in the final.<ref name="twic661">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic661.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 661|date=9 July 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-02-04| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080131175951/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic661.html| archivedate= 31 January 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *July 15 - [[Fabiano Caruana]] becomes the youngest ever Grandmaster in the history of both the United States and Italy surpassing the prior record of [[Hikaru Nakamura]].<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=3999|title=Fabiano Caruana – youngest US and Italian GM in history |periodical=ChessBase News|date=20 July 2007|accessdate=2009-03-01}}</ref> *July 15 – [[Canadian Chess Championship|Canadian Open]] in [[Ottawa]] won by GM [[Bu Xiangzhi]] (China) with 8/10 in a field of 280 players.<ref name="twic662">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic662.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 662|date=16 July 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-02-04| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080125160725/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic662.html| archivedate= 25 January 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *July 15 – [[Slovak Chess Championship|Slovak Championship]] in [[Banska Stiavnica]] won by GM [[Sergei Movsesian]] with 7½/9.<ref name="twic663">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic663.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 663|date=23 July 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-02-04| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080131180005/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic663.html| archivedate= 31 January 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *July 15 – [[Swedish Chess Championship|Swedish Championship]] in [[Stockholm]] won by GM [[Tiger Hillarp Persson]] with 9/13.<ref name="twic662"/> *July 15 – [[Scottish Chess Championship|Scottish Championship]] in [[Cumbernauld]] won by FM [[Andrew Muir]] with 8/9.<ref name="twic662"/> *July 20 – [[U.S. Women's Chess Championship|U.S. Women's Championship]] in [[Stillwater, Oklahoma]] won by IM [[Irina Krush]] with 7/9. Krush had also won the title in 1998.<ref name="twic663"/><ref>{{citation|last=Bird|first=Chris|title=Krush Wins Her Second Championship|url=http://main.uschess.org/content/view/7902/329/|periodical=Chess Life Online|date=1 October 2007|accessdate=2008-05-28| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080705173408/http://main.uschess.org/content/view/7902/329/| archivedate= 5 July 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *July 22 – [[Montenegro Chess Championship|Montenegro Championship]] in [[Cetinje]] won by GM [[Dragisa Blagojevic]] with 8½/11.<ref name="twic663"/> *July 22 – World Computer Rapid Championship on [[Internet Chess Club|ICC]] won by [[Rybka]] with 13/14.<ref name="twic663"/> *July 28 – 8th Montreal International won by GM [[Vassily Ivanchuk]] (Ukraine) with 7/9.<ref name="twic664">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic664.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 664|date=30 July 2007|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-02-04| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080125162935/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic664.html| archivedate= 25 January 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *July 28 – [[Montenegro Chess Championship|Montenegro Women's Championship]] in [[Cetinje]] won by WFM [[Aleksandra Mijovic]] with 7½/8.<ref name="twic664"/> *July 29 – 29th Politiken Cup in [[Copenhagen]] won by GM [[Michał Krasenkow]] (Poland) on tie-break over GM [[Emanuel Berg]] (Sweden), GM [[Gabriel Sargissian]] (Armenia), GM [[Nick de Firmian]] (USA), and GM [[Vladimir Malakhov (chess player)|Vladimir Malakhov]] (Russia) after they all finished on 8/10.<ref name="twic664"/>
===August=== *August 3 – 40th Biel Festival *August 5 – Baltic Sea Cup in [[Bornholm]] *August 11 – 94th [[British Chess Championship|British Championship]] in [[Great Yarmouth]] *August 18 – 5th Staunton Memorial at [[Simpson's-in-the-Strand]], London, features six British and six Dutch players (11 GMs, 1 WGM, category 13) in a single round-robin. GM [[Michael Adams (chess player)|Michael Adams]] (England) is the individual winner with 8½/11. The Dutch players compile a higher total score: Netherlands 38, UK 28.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.howardstaunton.com/hsmt2007/index.shtml|title=5th Howard Staunton Memorial 2007|accessdate=2008-01-24| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080130065051/http://www.howardstaunton.com/hsmt2007/index.shtml| archivedate= 30 January 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
===September=== *'''September 30''' – [[Viswanathan Anand]] becomes the new [[World Chess Championship|World Champion]] by winning the eight-player, double [[round-robin tournament|round-robin]] [[World Chess Championship 2007|2007 World Championship]] tournament in Mexico City.
===November=== *November 29 – [[World Youth Chess Championship|World Youth Championships]] in [[Antalya]]
===December=== *December 4 – 66th [[Italian Chess Championship|Italian Championship]] in [[Cremona]] *December 10 – [[Commonwealth Chess Championship|Commonwealth Championship]] in [[New Dehli]] won by GM [[Ramachandran Ramesh|G. B. Ramesh]] (India) on tie-break over GM [[Ganguly Surya Shekhar]] (India). The women's champion is IM [[Dronavalli Harika]] (India) who finished seventh overall. Indian players win 44 of the 45 medals awarded at the tournament.<ref>{{citation|last=Zaveri |first=Praful |url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=4355 |title=Ramesh is the Commonwealth Chess Champion |date=2 January 2008 |periodical=ChessBase News |accessdate=23 January 2008 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080105035002/http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=4355 |archivedate=5 January 2008 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> *December 16 – 91st [[Marshall Chess Club]] Championship won by GM [[Jaan Ehlvest]] (USA) for the fourth time, 6½/9.<ref>[http://www.marshallchessclub.org/MccCh2007/mccch07.htm crosstable] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509191818/http://www.marshallchessclub.org/MccCh2007/mccch07.htm |date=2008-05-09 }} at Marshall Chess Club web site</ref><ref name="twic690"> {{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic690.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 690|date=28 January 2008|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2008-01-20| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080130183211/http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic690.html| archivedate= 30 January 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> *'''December 30''' – [[Chess World Cup 2007|2007 World Cup]] in [[Khanty-Mansiysk]] won by GM [[Gata Kamsky]] (USA). As the winner of this 128-player [[single-elimination tournament]], Kamsky will play former world champion GM [[Veselin Topalov]] (Bulgaria) for the right to play in the [[World Chess Championship 2010|2010 World Championship]] match.
==Deaths== *January 17 – [[Rodrigo Flores]] (1913–2007), 93, eleven-time [[Chilean Chess Championship|Chilean champion]]. *May 21 – [[Alexander Roshal]] (1936–2007), 70, Russian chess journalist, editor of ''[[64 (chess magazine)|64-Chess Review]]'', responsible for restoration of the [[Chess Oscar]] as an annual award.<ref name="twic655"/> *June 8 - [[Fenny Heemskerk]] (1919–2007), 87, ten-time [[Dutch Chess Championship|Dutch Ladies' Champion]]. *July 1 – [[Maxim Sorokin]] (1968–2007), 38, Russian Grandmaster.<ref name="twic660"/> *November 27 – IM [[Svein Johannessen]] (1937–2007), 70. [[Norwegian Chess Championship|Norwegian Champion]] 1959, 1962, 1970 and 1973.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{chess}}

{{Infobox venue | name = Stade Barthélemy Boganda | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = | caption = | fullname = | former names = |pushpin_map = Central African Republic | map_size = 350px | pushpin_map_alt = | pushpin_map_caption = | pushpin_relief = | pushpin_label = | pushpin_label_position = |coordinates = {{Coord|4.3744|18.5643}} | location = Avenue de France,
[[Bangui]], [[Central African Republic]] | broke_ground = | built = | opened = December 2006http://china.aiddata.org/projects/352?iframe=y | renovated = | expanded = | owner = | operator = | surface = Grass | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 20,000[http://www.worldstadiums.com/africa/countries/car.shtml Central African Republic on worldstadiums.com] | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | field_shape = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = [[Central African Republic national football team]] | embedded = | website = }} '''Stade Barthélemy Boganda''', in [[Bangui]], is the national [[stadium]] of the [[Central African Republic]]. It is located at Complexe Sportif Barthélemy Boganda and it is currently used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches. The stadium has a capacity of 20,000 people. It is named after the former president of the country, [[Barthélemy Boganda]]. It was first constructed in 2003 by the Chinese company ''Complan'', it first started on 16 June 2006 and completed on 30 December by president [[François Bozizé]]{{cite web|url=http://www1.rfi.fr/actufr/articles/084/article_48550.asp|title=Un vrai stade à Bangui|trans-title=The Right Stadium in Bangui|publisher=RFI|language=fr|date=31 December 2006}} The stadium is home to one of several popular clubs in the country including [[AS Tempête Mocaf]] == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070804195927/http://www.sozoala.com/ Photograph galleries including pictures of the stadium] {{coord|4|22|27.9|N|18|33|51.8|E|type:landmark|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Barthelemy Boganda Stadium}} [[Category:Football venues in the Central African Republic]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in the Central African Republic]] [[Category:National stadiums|Central African Republic]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Bangui]] {{CentralAfricanRepublic-sports-venue-stub}}
