{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Edward A. LeLacheur Park | nickname = | image = [[File:Lelacheur.gif|275px]] | caption = LeLacheur Park | location = 450 Aiken Street
[[Lowell, Massachusetts]] 01854 | coordinates = {{coord|42.65327|-71.318114|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = 1996 | built = | opened = June 22, 1998 | closed = | demolished = | owner = City of Lowell | operator = Lowell Spinners | surface = Grass | construction_cost = $11.2 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|11200000|1998}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = [[Populous (company)|Populous]] | general_contractor = Peabody Construction Co., Inc.{{cite web |title=Mike McLaughlin Experience|url=https://www.linkedin.com/pub/mike-mclaughlin/14/3a2/b10|publisher=LinkedIn|accessdate=June 2, 2014}} | former_names = | tenants = [[Lowell Spinners]] ([[New York–Penn League|NYPL]]) (1998–present)
[[UMass Lowell River Hawks baseball|UMass Lowell River Hawks]] ([[NCAA Division I]] [[America East Conference|America East]]) (1998–present) | seating_capacity = 4,797 seated (5,030 with standing room)[http://www.milb.com/content/page.jsp?ymd=20081223&content_id=41221430&sid=t558&vkey=team4 "Franchise History"]. ''Milb.com''. Accessed September 9, 2016. | dimensions = '''Left Field:''' {{convert|337|ft|m}}
'''Left-Center Field:''' {{convert|368|ft|m}}
'''Center Field:''' {{convert|400|ft|m}}
'''Right-Center Field:''' {{convert|368|ft|m}}
'''Right Field:''' {{convert|301|ft|m}} }} '''Edward A. LeLacheur Park''' is a [[baseball park]] located on the banks of the [[Merrimack River]] in [[Lowell, Massachusetts]]. It is home to the [[New York–Penn League]] [[Lowell Spinners]], the [[minor league baseball|Class A]] Short Season Affiliate of the [[Boston Red Sox]]. LeLacheur Park is also home to the [[UMass Lowell River Hawks baseball]] team, which currently competes in the [[America East]] Conference at the [[NCAA Division I]] level as of the start of the [[2014 NCAA Division I baseball season|2014 season]]. ==History== The park was built between a partnership with the city of Lowell and the [[University of Massachusetts Lowell]]. The park was named for State Representative [[Edward A. LeLacheur]], who led the initial redevelopment of Lowell, and opened in 1998.{{cite news|last1=Collins|first1=John|title='There will never be another Ed LeLacheur'|url=http://www.lowellsun.com/rss/ci_15740893|accessdate=April 29, 2016|work=Lowell Sun|date=August 11, 2010}}{{cite news|last1=Girard|first1=Christopher J.|title=Edward A. LeLacheur, 85, longtime state legislator who quietly served others|url=http://archive.boston.com/bostonglobe/obituaries/articles/2010/08/08/edward_a_lelacheur_85_longtime_state_legislator_who_quietly_served_others/|accessdate=April 29, 2016|work=Boston.com|date=August 8, 2010}} The park was built adjacent to the residential section of UML. [[Populous (company)|Populous]] (formerly HOK Sport) designed the park. It offers views of the Aiken Street Bridge, Lawrence Mills, Fox Hall, and University Suites. The seating bowl is raised above the field. A concourse surrounds the top of the park where the refreshment, merchandise stands, and bathrooms are located. The design enables an open view while waiting in line. Two seating expansions have been considered since the park opened. One plan would have added 600-1,000 seats on the third base side. The expansion would match how the first base side is angled towards the infield. The other proposal was to add a smaller version of the [[Green Monster]] with seating for approximately 200 people. This would also would have shortened the field and raised the wall to {{convert|20|ft|m|abbr=on}}. Due to lack of funds, neither have been built.{{cite news |title=Lowell Spinners Pitching a Monster of an Idea for LeLacheur|first=Jennifer|last=Myers|url=http://www.lowellsun.com/ci_13176051|newspaper=[[The Sun (Lowell)|Lowell Sun]]|date=August 21, 2009|accessdate=June 2, 2014}} The stadium also features the Giant Hood Milk Jug from [[Fenway Park]] and all Red Sox [[squad number#Retired numbers|retired numbers]]. The ballpark held its first concert on July 10, 2008 when Boston-based Celtic punk band [[Dropkick Murphys]] played there with [[The Mighty Mighty Bosstones]].{{cite news |title=A Rockin' Grand Slam at Lowell's LeLacheur Park|first=Rachel R.|last=Briere|url=http://www.lowellsun.com/ci_9849261|newspaper=[[The Sun (Lowell)|Lowell Sun]]|date=July 11, 2008|accessdate=June 2, 2014}} ==Attendance== The Spinners have had several consecutive sold-out seasons at LeLacheur Park.{{cite web |title=Spinners Record Book|url=http://www.milb.com/content/page.jsp?ymd=20090909&content_id=6877092&sid=t558&vkey=roster|publisher=Minor League Baseball|date=September 9, 2009|accessdate=June 3, 2014}}{{cite web |title=Franchise History|url=http://www.milb.com/content/page.jsp?ymd=20081223&content_id=41221430&fext=.jsp&vkey=news_t558&sid=t558|publisher=Minor League Baseball|date=December 23, 2008|accessdate=June 3, 2014}} ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Edward A. LeLacheur Park}} *[http://www.lowellspinners.com Lowell Spinners home page] *[http://www.goriverhawks.com/sports/2012/2/29/general_0229123653.aspx?tab=facilities UMass Lowell Athletics: Facilities] *[http://www.littleballparks.com/Stadium/2004/Lowell/Lowell.htm Edward A. Lelacheur Park Views – ''Ball Parks of the Minor Leagues''] {{University of Massachusetts Lowell}} {{NYPL Ballparks}} {{America East Conference baseball venue navbox}} {{Massachusetts NCAA Division I college baseball venue navbox}} {{Greater Boston sports arenas}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Edward A. Lelacheur Park}} [[Category:Baseball venues in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:UMass Lowell River Hawks baseball]] [[Category:Sports venues in Lowell, Massachusetts]] [[Category:1998 establishments in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1998]] [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]]

[[Marcela Ivon Rodezno Hernández]] (4–3) | Most ties = Ingrid González (36) | Most years = Ingrid González (9) }} The '''El Salvador Fed Cup team''' represents [[El Salvador]] in [[Fed Cup]] [[tennis]] competition and are governed by the [[Federación Salvadorena de Tenis]]. They have not competed since [[2013 Fed Cup|2013]]. ==History== El Salvador competed in its first Fed Cup in [[1992 Federation Cup (tennis)|1992]]. Their best result was reaching the Group I promotion play-offs in [[2003 Fed Cup|2003]] and [[2004 Fed Cup|2004]]. ==See also== *[[Fed Cup]] *[[El Salvador Davis Cup team]] ==External links== *{{FedCupteamlink|code=ESA}} {{Fed Cup}} [[Category:Fed Cup teams]] [[Category:Tennis in El Salvador|Fed Cup]] [[Category:National sports teams of El Salvador|Fed Cup]] {{FedCup-stub}} {{ElSalvador-sport-stub}}

{{unref|date=January 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox football club | clubname = Fraternidad Tigres | image = | fullname = Fraternidad Tigres | nickname = "Los Artilleros" | founded = June 1999 | ground = [[Estadio Hernando Siles]]
[[La Paz, Bolivia]] | capacity = 45,000 | chairman = {{flagicon|BOL}} [[Juan Carlos]] | manager = {{flagicon|BOL}} Mario Fernandez| | season = [[Liga de Fútbol Profesional Boliviano 2009|LFPB – 2009]] | league = [[Copa Simón Bolívar]] | position = |pattern_la1=_sl1011h|pattern_b1=_sl1011h|pattern_ra1=_sl1011h | leftarm1=000080|body1=FF0000 |rightarm1=000080|shorts1=000080|socks1=000080 | pattern_la2=_sl1011a|pattern_b2=_sl1011a|pattern_ra2=_sl1011a | leftarm2=FFFFFF|body2=FFFFFF|rightarm2=FFFFFF|shorts2=000080|socks2=FFFFFF |current = 2009 Copa Simón Bolívar }} '''Fraternidad Tigres''' is a [[football (soccer)|football]] club from [[La Paz]] that plays in the La Paz Primera A, one of the third division regional leagues. The club was founded on 6 June 1999 and plays its home games at the [[Estadio Hernando Siles]]. {{redirect|Gil Thorpe|the ''Modern Family'' character|List of Modern Family characters#Introduced in season 4}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox comic strip | title = Gil Thorp | image = [[File:Gil Thorp 2011-10-17.gif|240px]] | caption = Gil Thorp coaching a Milford football player | creator = Jack Berrill (creator) | current = [[Neal Rubin]] (writer)
Rod Whigham (artist) | url = [http://www.gocomics.com/gilthorp gocomics.com/gilthorp] | status = Running | first = September 8, 1958 | last = | altnames = | syndicate = [[Tribune Content Agency]]{{cite web |title=Gil Thorp comics by Neal Rubin and Rod Whigham |url=https://tribunecontentagency.com/premium-content/comics/gil-thorp/ |website=Tribune Content Agency |accessdate=9 October 2018}} | genre = Sports }} '''''Gil Thorp''''' is a sports-oriented [[comic strip]] which has been published since September 8, 1958. The main character, Gil Thorp, is the athletic director of Milford High School and coaches the [[American football|football]], basketball, and baseball teams. In addition to the sports storylines, the strip also deals with issues facing teenagers such as teen pregnancy, [[anabolic steroid|steroids]], and drug abuse. ==History== The strip was created by Jack Berrill, who modeled and named Thorp after baseball player [[Gil Hodges]] and Olympic athlete [[Jim Thorpe]]. Berrill continued the strip until he died of cancer on March 14, 1996. Over the course of his 38 years, Berrill broke ground with many of his stories, often dealing with sensitive social issues of the day. As editorial standards relaxed, he was able to move from stories about jalopies and after-school jobs to topics like teen pregnancy, divorce, and steroids. ===Writers=== Upon Berrill's death, Tribune Media Services chose author [[Jerry Jenkins]] (co-author of the ''[[Left Behind (series)|Left Behind]]'' novels) to take over writing the strip. Jenkins had been in discussions with TMS about expanding previous ''Gil Thorp'' stories into a series of youth novels and was a logical replacement. Many of Jenkins' stories were written uncredited by his son Chad Jenkins, a baseball coach at [[Bethel College (Indiana)|Bethel College]]. The Jenkins stories discussed overtly religious topics which had not appeared in the strip before, including an [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox Jewish]] football player and a 15-year-old pregnant girl whom Thorp talks out of getting an abortion. In 2004, Jenkins was followed as writer by ''[[Detroit News]]'' columnist [[Neal Rubin]]. ===Artists=== The strip was drawn by Berrill from 1958–1993 until [[glaucoma]] forced him to turn the reins over to his Connecticut Cartoonist Associate colleague [[Warren Sattler]]. Later [[Frank Bolle]] took over. Later Ray Burns took over. [[Frank McLaughlin (artist)|Frank McLaughlin]] took over following Burns' death in 2000. On February 18, 2008, ''[[Apartment 3G]]'' artist Frank Bolle again took over art chores for ''Gil Thorp'' on an interim basis. Rod Whigham became the permanent artist two months later. ==The Bucket== The Bucket was an online forum hosted by the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', named after the teen burger hangout in the strip, The Bucket. It was a lively site for 15 years and featured discussions about the strip and other topics. Members of the community were known as "Bucketeers".{{cn|date=June 2013}} ==References== {{reflist|refs= {{cite news |first=Michael |last=Miner |work=[[Chicago Reader]] |title=Good Sports, Bad Sports |url=http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/good-sports-bad-sports-tribs-buddy-system/Content?oid=895476 |date=February 5, 1998 |accessdate=January 23, 2012}} {{cite news |first=Michael |last=Miner |work=[[Chicago Reader]] |title=Gil Thorp Gets Benched |url=http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/gil-thorp-gets-benchedfor-a-moment-we-were-scaredsafety-secondwhile-they-were-sleeping/Content?oid=911807 |date=April 17, 2003 |accessdate=January 23, 2012}} {{cite news |first=Daniel |last=Fleishman |title=Who Was That Yarmulke-topped Man? 'Gil Thorp' Strip Gets Sabbath-observant Character |work=[[Jewish World Review]] |date=August 28, 2001}} {{cite news |work=The Comics Reporter |title=Rubin Debut Ends "Passion of Gil Thorp" |url=http://www.comicsreporter.com/index.php/resources/longbox/2089/ |date=April 17, 2004 |accessdate=January 23, 2012}} {{cite news |title=New Artist Set to Take Over ''Gil Thorp'' Strip |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |date=March 3, 2008}} {{cite news |first=Mike |last=Downey |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |title=Timeless classic Gil Thorp looks at life on and off the fields of play |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2008-09-07/sports/0809060122_1_gil-thorp-neal-rubin-comic-strip |date=September 7, 2008 |accessdate=January 23, 2012}} }} ==External links== *[http://www.gocomics.com/gilthorp/ Gil Thorp on GoComics.com] *[http://toonopedia.com/gilthorp.htm ''Gil Thorp''] at [[Don Markstein's Toonopedia]]. [https://www.webcitation.org/6k6xATUWg Archived] from the original on August 28, 2016. *[http://www.chicagoreader.com/hottype/2003/030418_1.html "Gil Thorp Gets Benched"] by Michael Miner, ''[[Chicago Reader]]'', April 18, 2003 {{Tribune Company}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gil Thorp}} [[Category:American comic strips]] [[Category:1958 comics debuts]] [[Category:American football comics]] [[Category:Baseball comics]] [[Category:Basketball comics]] [[Category:Drama comics]] [[Category:Slice of life comics]] [[Category:Fictional schoolteachers|Thorp, Gil]] [[Category:American comics characters|Thorp, Gil]] [[Category:Fictional American people|Thorp, Gil]] [[Category:Male characters in comics|Thorp, Gil]] [[Category:Comics characters introduced in 1958|Thorp, Gil]] [[Category:Comics set in the United States]] [[Category:Comic strips syndicated by Tribune Content Agency]] [[Category:GoComics]] [[Category:Sports comics]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox website | name = Ivy League Digital Network | logo = | logocaption = | screenshot = | collapsible = | collapsetext = | caption = | url = {{URL|ivyleaguedigitalnetwork.com}} | slogan = | type = [[Broadcasting of sports events|Sports broadcasting]] | registration = | language = | num_users = | content_license = | owner = Council of Ivy Group Presidents | author = | editor = | launch_date = {{Start date and age|2013|06|28|df=yes}} | alexa = | revenue = | current_status = Discontinued July 12, 2018 | footnotes = }}
'''Ivy League Digital Network''' was an [[Internet television]] website and operated by the [[Ivy League]]. The internet network was first available to subscribers in the fall of 2013, and covered all eight of the [[Ivy League]] schools. The site used technology provided by [[NeuLion]] to feature live and on-demand content from a variety of sports across the eight schools and conference championship events.<ref>http://www.ivyleaguedigitalnetwork.com/page/aboutus</ref> On April 4, 2018, it was announced that the Ivy League and [[ESPN]] agreed having the ESPN platform carry Ivy League athletic competitions.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/college-sports/story/_/id/23030560/ivy-league-espn-announce-10-year-deal-network-air-sporting-events-espn+|title=ESPN, Ivy League announce 10-year deal to air games on new ESPN+|last=|first=|date=2018-04-04|work=ESPN.com|access-date=2018-08-14|language=en}}</ref> Under the ten year deal, over 1,100 Ivy League events per year across 30 sports will be covered, including certain premier Ivy League events (e.g., the Harvard-Yale football game) which will air on its Linear Networks, but with the majority of sports and events being carried on [[ESPN+]], its new direct-to-consumer streaming service that was launched on April 12, 2018. On July 12, 2018, the Ivy League Digital Network announced that their website would no longer provide services, all users' subscriptions would be automatically cancelled, and user should purchase a subrscription to ESPN+ to continue to watch Ivy League athletic competitions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ivyleague.com/news/2018/7/3/general-ivy-league-network-moves-to-espn.aspx?path=general|title=Ivy League Network — ESPN FAQ page|last=|first=|date=2018-07-12|website=Ivy League Digital Network|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-14}}</ref>
==Programming==
*Baseball *Basketball (Men's and Women's) *Cross Country *Field Hockey *Football *Golf (Men's and Women's) *Women's Gymnastics *Ice Hockey (Men's and Women's) *Indoor T&F *Lacrosse (Men's and Women's) *Outdoor T&F *Rowing (Men's and Women's) *Women's Rugby *Soccer (Men's and Women's) *Softball *Sprint Football *Squash (Men's and Women's) *Swimming/Diving (Men's and Women's) *Tennis (Men's and Women's) *Volleyball (Men's and Women's) *Water-polo (Men's and Women's) *Wrestling
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.ivyleaguedigitalnetwork.com/ Ivy League Digital Network]
{{Ivy League}}

{{Refimprove|date=January 2008}} This is a list of individuals, groups of individuals, and companies who have owned and operated a professional sports organization. The list is organized first by sport, then by franchise or team, then by Owner. If an organization has gone through a significant change (e.g. the team has moved and/or changed names), that information is noted after the years of ownership. == Association football club owners == === England === {{main|List of English football club owners}} ==== [[Premier League]] owners ==== ;[[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] *[[Stan Kroenke]] *[[Alisher Usmanov]] ;[[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] *Owned by a large number of shareholders until 1968. Since that time: *[[Doug Ellis]] (largest single shareholder 1968–1975; majority shareholder 1982–2006) *[[Randy Lerner]] (2006–2016) *[[Tony Xia|Recon Sports Limited]] (2016-present) ;[[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] *[[Roman Abramovich]] ;[[Everton F.C.|Everton]] *[[Bill Kenwright]] ;[[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] *[[Shahid Khan]] ;[[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] * Moores family, among them [[John Moores (merchant)|John Moores]] and [[David Moores]] (1930s-2007) * [[George N. Gillett Jr.|George Gillett]], [[Tom Hicks]] (2007–2010) * [[Fenway Sports Group]] (2010–present); [[LeBron James]] acquired a minority interest in April 2011 ;[[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] *Manchester City Limited — The club's holding company; owned by a large number of shareholders until 2007 (see [[Ownership of Manchester City F.C.]]). Since then, the holding company has been owned by: **[[Thaksin Shinawatra]] (2007–2008) **[[Abu Dhabi United Group]] (2008–present) ;[[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] *Manchester United plc (NYSE : MANU) – The club's holding company, owned by shareholders. Lerner]] – ([[2006 in baseball|2006]]-present) === Nippon Professional Baseball owners === In Japanese baseball, teams are traditionally owned by companies and bear that company's name. Only one team in recent years has not borne a corporate name—the Yokohama BayStars went without a corporate name from 1993 through 2011 because its owner chose not to attach its name to the team. {{distinguish|text=the Long Room at [[Trinity College Library]]}} [[File:Lords Long Room.jpg|right|300px|thumb|The Long Room in the Lords pavilion]] '''The Long Room''' is a notable, historic room at [[Lord's cricket ground]], in [[St John's Wood]], [[London]].
Described by [[Lawrence Booth (cricket writer)|Lawrence Booth]] as "the most evocative four walls in world cricket",<ref name="Booth">Arm-Ball to Zooter, Lawrence Booth, Penguin 2006, {{ISBN|0-14-051581-X}}, p.150-1</ref> the Long Room is situated in the [[Lord's Pavilion|Pavilion]].
==Function==
Players walk through the Long Room on their way from the dressing rooms to the [[cricket field]]; this walk is notoriously long and complex at Lord's. On his Test debut in 1975, [[David Steele (cricketer)|David Steele]] got lost "and ended up in the pavilion's basement toilets".<ref name="Booth"/>
Members of [[Marylebone Cricket Club|MCC]] and their guests have free access to the room (there are windows with views of the ground) and will often greet [[Australia national cricket team|Australian]] [[batsman|batsmen]] with "witticisms ... like 'See you soon'".<ref name="Booth"/> On this point, Australian [[Justin Langer]],<ref>Langer also played at Lord's on many occasions as a (home) [[Middlesex County Cricket Club|Middlesex player]]</ref> described walking through the Long Room like "being bearhugged by an invisible spirit".<ref name="Booth"/>
As a result of the [[Pakistan cricket spot-fixing scandal]], news of which broke on the last morning of the [[Pakistani cricket team in England in 2010#Fourth Test|2010 Lord's Test match]], the presentation ceremony at the end of the match (and series) was held in the Long Room, rather than on the pitch.
The Long Room has recently been made available on a private hire basis for events such as weddings and conferences.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://hirespace.com/Spaces/1057/Lords-Cricket-Ground/The-Long-Room/Events |title=United Kingdom: The Long Room : Events Hire |accessdate=17 Feb 2014 }}</ref>
==Decor==
The Long Room is lined with paintings of famous cricketers and administrators, from the 18th century to the 21st. For contemporary or overseas players to have their portrait placed here is a considerable honour and very few have been awarded this distinction. For example, only four Australian cricketers have ever been honoured in this way: Sir [[Don Bradman|Donald Bradman]], [[Keith Miller]], [[Victor Trumper]] and [[Shane Warne]],<ref>The following sources are, respectively, a Miller obituary from 2004, which lists Trumper and Bradman and a further piece from 2005, when Warne's portrait was added. [[Michael Atherton]], the author of the second piece, curiously overlooks Trumper's portrait; other articles of the same period do similarly.</ref><ref name="Selvey">{{cite news | first = Mike | last = Selvey | authorlink = Mike Selvey | title = Obituary: Keith Miller | url = https://www.theguardian.com/australia/story/0,,1325266,00.html | publisher = [[The Guardian]] | date = 2004-10-12 | accessdate = 2008-01-14 | location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml?xml=/sport/2005/06/12/scwarn12.xml | work=The Daily Telegraph | location=London | title=Warne: still the incomparable master of spin bowler's craft | first=Michael | last=Atherton | date=2005-06-12 | accessdate=2010-05-11}}</ref> the only one of the four to have played international cricket in the last 60 years.<ref>Miller's last Test was in 1956. Only Warne, born in 1969 with a Test career from 1992–2007, has played more recently.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox National Olympic Committee | title = Luxembourgish Olympic and Sporting Committee | logo = Luxembourgish Olympic and Sporting Committee logo.svg | size = 100px | country = Luxembourg | code = LUX | created = 1912 | recognized = 1912 | association = EOC | headquarters = [[Strassen, Luxembourg|Strassen]], [[Luxembourg]] | president = [[André Hoffmann (lawyer)|André Hoffmann]] | secretary general = [[Daniel Dax]] | website = [http://teamletzebuerg.lu/ www.teamletzebuerg.lu] }} The '''Luxembourgian Olympic and Sporting Committee''' ({{lang-lb|Lëtzebuerger Olympesche a Sporting Comité}}, {{lang-fr|Comité Olympique et Sportif Luxembourgeois}}, {{lang-de|Luxemburgisch Olympic und Sportausschuss}}), abbreviated to '''COSL''', is the [[National Olympic Committee]] for [[Luxembourg]].

page.title: Major sports event hosting in Britain during the 2010s

revision.text:
[[File:Olympic Stadium (London), 16 April 2012.jpg|thumb|300px|The 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games were one of several international sporting events held in Britain during the 2010s decade.]]
The [[United Kingdom]] has been awarded, or is bidding to hold, a number of major international sporting events during the 2010s leading to an idea of a 'Golden Decade' in British sport.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml?xml=/sport/2007/11/01/sfnbri101.xml.htm |work= telegraph.co.uk |title= Golden Decade |date= 1 November 2007 |accessdate= 2008-01-27 | location=London}}</ref> The idea of the golden decade has been discussed in many newspapers and has been mentioned by former Prime Minister [[Gordon Brown]] and [[Sebastian Coe|Lord Coe]].
==Timeline of events==
===2010=== 14–18 April – [[2010 European Badminton Championships]] at the [[Manchester Arena]] in [[Manchester]]
7–17 July – [[2010 Wheelchair Basketball World Championship]] at the [[National Indoor Arena]] in [[Birmingham]]
15–24 July – [[2010 World Lacrosse Championship]] at the [[University of Manchester]] in Manchester
17 July – Completion of the [[Clipper Round the World Yacht Race|2009–10 Clipper Round the World Yacht Race]] in [[Kingston upon Hull|Hull]]
20 August–5 September – [[2010 Women's Rugby World Cup|Women's Rugby World Cup]] in [[London]]
1–4 October – [[2010 Ryder Cup|Ryder Cup]] at [[Celtic Manor Resort]] in [[Newport, Wales|Newport]]
21–28 November – [[2010 ATP World Tour Finals|ATP World Tour Finals]] at [[The O2 Arena]] in London
===2011=== 20–21 May – [[2010–11 European Challenge Cup#Final|Amlin Challenge Cup]] and [[2011 Heineken Cup Final|Heineken Cup Finals]] in at the [[Cardiff City Stadium]] and [[Millennium Stadium]] in [[Cardiff]]
26 May – [[2011 UEFA Women's Champions League Final|Women's Champions League Final]] at [[Craven Cottage]] in London
28 May – [[2011 UEFA Champions League Final|Champions League Final]] at [[Wembley Stadium]] in London
3–7 August – [[International Children's Games]] in [[Lanarkshire]]
8–14 August – [[2011 BWF World Championships|BWF World Championships]] at [[Wembley Arena]] in London
17–20 November – [[2011 Trampoline World Championships]] at the [[National Indoor Arena]] in Birmingham
20–27 November – ATP World Tour Finals at The O2 Arena in London
===2012=== 20–26 February – [[FINA Diving World Cup|2012 FINA Diving World Cup]] at the [[London Aquatics Centre]] in London
3–6 May – [[2012 European Taekwondo Championships]] at SportCity in Manchester
18–19 May – [[2011–12 European Challenge Cup|Amlin Challenge Cup]] and [[2011–12 Heineken Cup|Heineken Cup Finals]] at the [[Twickenham Stoop]] and [[Twickenham Stadium]] in London
27 July–12 August – [[2012 Summer Olympics|Summer Olympics]] in London
29 August–9 September – [[2012 Summer Paralympics|Summer Paralympics]] in London
16–18 November – [[UCI Track Cycling World Cup Classics|UCI Track Cycling World Cup]] at the [[Sir Chris Hoy Velodrome]] in Glasgow
November – ATP World Tour Finals at The O2 Arena in London
===2013=== 21 April – [[International Paralympic Committee|IPC Athletics Marathon World Cup]] in London
10–12 May – [[2012–13 Euroleague Final Four|2013 EuroLeague Final Four]] at The O2 Arena in London
23 May – [[2013 UEFA Women's Champions League Final]] at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] in London
25 May – [[2013 UEFA Champions League Final]] at Wembley Stadium in London
6–23 June – [[2013 ICC Champions Trophy]] at [[The Oval]], [[Edgbaston Cricket Ground|Edgbaston]] and [[SWALEC Stadium|Cardiff]]
21–23 June – [[World Rowing Cup|2013 World Rowing Cup]] at [[Eton Dorney]] in [[Windsor, Berkshire|Windsor]]
1–10 August – [[World Police and Fire Games|2013 World Police and Fire Games]] in [[Belfast]]
3–4 August – [[Prudential Ride London]], Grand Prix, London-Surrey 100 & London-Surrey Classic
7–11 August – [[UCI Juniors Track World Championships]] at the Sir Chris Hoy Velodrome in Glasgow
1 September – Beginning of the [[Clipper Round the World Yacht Race]] at [[St Katharine Docks]] in London
11–15 September – [[2013 ITU World Triathlon Series|ITU World Triathlon Series]] Final at [[Hyde Park, London|Hyde Park]] in London
26 October–30 November – [[2013 Rugby League World Cup|Rugby League World Cup]] in [[England]] and [[Wales]]
1–3 November – UCI Track Cycling World Cup at the [[Manchester Velodrome]] in Manchester
4–11 November – [[2013 ATP World Tour Finals|ATP World Tour Finals]] at The O2 Arena in London
===2014=== 13 April – IPC Athletics Marathon World Cup in London
23–24 May – [[2013–14 European Challenge Cup|Amlin Challenge Cup]] and [[2013–14 Heineken Cup|Heineken Cup Finals]] at [[Cardiff Arms Park]] and the Millennium Stadium in Cardiff
26–29 June World Corporate Games Liverpool presented by the International festival of Business. Delivered at multiple sporting venues across the Liverpool and City region and St George's Hall
5–7 July – [[2014 Tour de France|Le Grand Depart, 2014 Tour de France]] in [[Leeds]] and London
24 July–3 August – [[2014 Commonwealth Games|Commonwealth Games]] in Glasgow
18–23 August – IPC Athletics European Championships at [[Swansea University]]
10–14 September – Invictus Games London 2014 at [[Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park]]
26–28 September – [[2014 Ryder Cup|Ryder Cup]] at [[Gleneagles Hotel|Gleneagles]]
9- 16 November – [[ATP World Tour Finals]] at The O2 Arena in London
26–30 November – [[Wheelchair Tennis Masters|NEC Wheelchair Tennis Masters]] at [[Eton Manor|Lee Valley Hockey and Tennis Centre]] in London
===2015=== 26 April – IPC Athletics Marathon World Cup in London
16–19 April – [[European Judo Championships]] in Glasgow
1–2 May – [[2014–15 European Rugby Challenge Cup|European Rugby Challenge Cup]] and [[2014–15 European Rugby Champions Cup|European Rugby Champions Cup Finals]] at the [[Twickenham Stoop]] and [[Twickenham Stadium]] in London
19–25 July – [[IPC Swimming World Championships|2015 IPC Swimming World Championships]] at [[Tollcross International Swimming Centre]] in Glasgow
31 July - 8 August – [[World Orienteering Championships]] in [[Inverness]]
1 - 30 August 2015 – [[EuroHockey Nations Championship]] at Lee Valley Hockey and Tennis Centre in London <ref>{{cite news|last=Farquhar|first=Gordon|title=London 2012: England to host 2015 EuroHockey tournament|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/hockey/17459172|accessdate=14 September 2012|newspaper=[[BBC Sport]]|date=21 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Unibet2015 EuroHockey tournament|url=http://eurohockey2015.co.uk/|accessdate=3 February 2016|date=}}</ref>
28 August - 6 September – [[European Wheelchair Basketball Championship]] 2015
18 September-31 October – [[2015 Rugby World Cup|Rugby World Cup]] in [[England]]
15–20 September – [[2015 ICF Canoe Slalom World Championships|ICF Canoe Slalom World Championships]] at [[Lee Valley White Water Centre]] in London
23 October-1 November – [[World Artistic Gymnastics Championships]] in [[Glasgow]]
26-30 November – [[Wheelchair Tennis Masters]] at Lee Valley Hockey and Tennis Centre in London
2-6 December – [[2015 ATP World Tour Finals|ATP World Tour Finals]] at The O<sub>2</sub> Arena in London
===2016=== 2–6 March – [[UCI Track Cycling World Championships|2016 UCI Track Cycling World Championships]] at the [[London Velodrome]] in London<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britishcycling.org.uk/about/article/bc20130925-British-Cycling-wins-bid-to-host-2016-UCI-Track-World-Championships-in-London-0 |title=British Cycling has been awarded the 2016 Track World Championships to be staged at the London velodrome, it has been announced today}}</ref>
24 April – IPC Athletics Marathon World Cup in London<ref>IPC Marathon World Cup to continue in London until 2017: http://www.paralympic.org/news/ipc-marathon-world-cup-continue-london-until-2017</ref>
9–22 May – [[2016 European Aquatics Championships|2016 LEN European Aquatics Championships]] at the [[London Aquatics Centre]] in London <ref name="LEN 2016 swimming">{{cite web |url=http://www.len.eu/Press/LEN%20allocates%202016%20European%20Championships%20to%20London.aspx |title=LEN allocates 2016 European Championships to London |date=27 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141027121514/http://www.len.eu/Press/LEN%20allocates%202016%20European%20Championships%20to%20London.aspx |archivedate=27 October 2014 |df= }}</ref>
18-26 June – Women's Hockey Champions Trophy at Lee Valley Hockey and Tennis Centre in London –
7–25 June – [[2016 World Rugby Under 20 Championship]] in [[Greater Manchester]]
13-20 November – ATP World Tour Finals at The O<sub>2</sub> Arena in London
Dates to be confirmed – [[Wheelchair Tennis Masters]] at Lee Valley Hockey and Tennis Centre in London
===2017=== April (dates to be confirmed) – IPC Athletics Marathon World Cup in London
12 and 13 May – [[2016–17 European Rugby Challenge Cup|2017 European Rugby Challenge Cup Final]] and [[2017 European Rugby Champions Cup Final]] at [[Murrayfield Stadium|Murrayfield]] in Edinburgh
1-18 June – [[2017 ICC Champions Trophy]] in England and Wales
13–22 July – [[2017 Women's Lacrosse World Cup]] at the [[Surrey Sports Park]] in Guildford
14–23 July – [[2017 World Para Athletics Championships]] at the [[London Stadium|Olympic Stadium]] in London
July (dates to be confirmed) – Men's Hockey World League Semi-Final 2 at Lee Valley Hockey and Tennis Centre in London
5–13 August – [[2017 World Championships in Athletics|2017 IAAF Athletics World Championships]] at the Olympic Stadium in London
8–25 August – [[2017 Women's Rugby World Cup]] in Dublin and Belfast – '''Co-hosted'''
12–19 November – [[2017 ATP Finals]] at The O<sub>2</sub> Arena in London
===2018=== 4–20 May - [[2018 UEFA European Under-17 Championship]]
14-15 July - Inaugural [[Athletics World Cup]] <ref>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/05/london-stadium-to-host-new-athletics-world-cup-in-july</ref>
7–21 July – [[Women's Hockey World Cup]] at Lee Valley Hockey and Tennis Centre in London
12–21 July – [[2019 Netball World Cup]] in Liverpool.
11–18 November – [[2018 ATP Finals]] at The O<sub>2</sub> Arena in London
===2019=== 10 and 11 May – [[2018–19 European Rugby Challenge Cup|2019 European Rugby Challenge Cup Final]] and [[2019 European Rugby Champions Cup Final]] at [[St James' Park]] in [[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle]]
30 May–14 July – [[2019 Cricket World Cup|2019 ICC Cricket World Cup]] in [[England]] and [[Wales]]
13–15 September – [[2019 Solheim Cup]] at [[Gleneagles Hotel|Gleneagles]] near [[Auchterarder]], [[Scotland]]
November (dates TBA) – 2019 ATP Finals at The O<sub>2</sub> Arena in London
<!--===2020=== July - [[UEFA Euro 2020]] finals at Wembley Stadium in London'-->
==Events hosted==
===2010 World Lacrosse Championships=== [[Manchester]] hosted the world's biggest lacrosse event in July 2010. It was the third edition of the [[World Lacrosse Championships]] held in [[England]], with Manchester hosting the [[1994 World Lacrosse Championship|1994 tournament]] and [[Stockport]] hosting in [[1978 World Lacrosse Championship|1978]]. The event took place at the [[University of Manchester]], on the same campus used for the athletes' village at the [[2002 Commonwealth Games]].
===2010 Women's Rugby World Cup=== The International Rugby Board, now known as [[World Rugby]], which governs [[rugby union]], announced in September 2008 that the [[2010 Women's Rugby World Cup]] would be held in [[London]].<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.irb.com/newsmedia/mediazone/pressrelease/newsid=2026944.html |title=England to host Women's RWC 2010 |publisher=International Rugby Board |date=2008-09-28 |accessdate=2009-07-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090819002932/http://www.irb.com/newsmedia/mediazone/pressrelease/newsid%3D2026944.html |archivedate=2009-08-19 |df= }}</ref> The event was held in late August and early September. All matches took place at the [[Surrey Sports Park]] in [[Guildford]], except for the semi-finals, third-place match, and final, which were held at the [[The Stoop|Twickenham Stoop]].
===2010 Ryder Cup=== The [[2010 Ryder Cup]] was held at the Celtic Manor Resort Hotel in [[Newport, Wales|Newport]], [[South Wales]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/golf/1569128.stm|title=Welsh bid chiefs delighted |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2001-09-28 |accessdate=2008-08-03}}</ref> Originally scheduled for 1–3 October, it was extended to 4 October due to delays caused by heavy rains.
===2011 European Rugby Challenge Cup and European Rugby Champions Cup=== [[Millennium Stadium]] hosted the [[2011 Heineken Cup Final]] on 21 May. This was the fourth time that the [[Cardiff]] venue, the home of [[Wales national rugby union team|Welsh rugby union]], hosted this event. The day before, the city also hosted the [[2010–11 European Challenge Cup#Final|final]] of the second-tier [[European Challenge Cup|Amlin Challenge Cup]] at [[Cardiff City Stadium]].
===2011 Women's Champions League and Champions League Finals=== [[Wembley Stadium]] hosted the [[2011 UEFA Champions League Final]] on 28 May. This was the first time the current Wembley had hosted the event; the [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|original Wembley Stadium]] had hosted the final five times. Including two finals at [[Hampden Park]] in [[Glasgow]] and one at [[Old Trafford]] in [[Manchester]], this was the ninth time that Britain had hosted the European Cup/Champions League final.
As a part of its successful bid, London was also awarded the [[2011 UEFA Women's Champions League Final]], which was held on 26 May at [[Craven Cottage]]. It was the first time Britain had hosted the final of the women's event.
===2011 International Children's Games=== [[Image:Dollan Baths, East Kilbride 1.jpg|thumb|Dollan Baths]] The [[International Children's Games]] is the world's largest international multi-sport youth event, with nearly 2,000 athletes, coaches and officials from over 70 countries taking part. The event is informally referred to as the 'Mini-Olympics'. [[Lanarkshire]] won the unanimous backing of the ICG Committee for hosting rights to the 2011 Games, beating strong competition from [[Singapore]] and [[Daegu]]. Scotland's First Minister [[Alex Salmond]] spoke to the Committee in a video message, pointing out that the awarding of the 2011 Games to Lanarkshire would be a major boost to the local area and informing them that the entire nation was supporting the bid. One of the prime venues was [[Strathclyde Country Park]], which is also an official [[2014 Commonwealth Games]] venue. Other venues included the new £29m sports facility at [[Ravenscraig]], the [[Historic Scotland]] Category A listed [[Dollan Baths]] and the Airdrie Lesiure Centre.
===2012 Amlin Challenge Cup and Heineken Cup Finals=== [[Twickenham Stadium|Twickenham]], home to both the [[England national rugby union team]] and England's [[Rugby Football Union|national governing body]] for the sport, hosted the [[2012 Heineken Cup Final]] on 19 May. As with Millennium Stadium the year before, this was the fourth final for Twickenham. The adjacent [[Twickenham Stoop]] hosted the [[2011–12 European Challenge Cup#Final|Amlin Challenge Cup final]] on the day before the Heineken Cup Final; this was the fourth Challenge Cup final at The Stoop.
===2012 Summer Olympics=== {{Main|2012 Summer Olympics}} After [[Birmingham]] and [[Manchester]] failed to deliver winning bids for the [[1992 Summer Olympics|1992]], [[1996 Summer Olympics|1996]] and [[2000 Summer Olympics|2000 Olympic Games]], the [[British Olympic Association]] (BOA) decided that London was the best choice to pursue the goal of hosting the Summer Olympics.<ref name="BBC London">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/olympics_2012/4233055.stm |title=Rivals for 2012: London |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=2005-06-08 |accessdate=2007-03-06}}</ref> The centrepiece of the London bid was the [[Lower Lea Valley]], the location designated to be transformed into a world-class [[Olympic Park, London|Olympic Park]] and [[Olympic Village]]. It would be connected via a high-speed [[Public transport|shuttle]] service, dubbed the [[Olympic Javelin]], and existing transport links capable of transferring 240,000 people per hour.<ref name="Train">{{cite web|url=http://www.alwaystouchout.com/project/44 |title=Stratford Olympic Park |date=2006-01-25 |accessdate=2007-03-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070320223510/http://www.alwaystouchout.com/project/44 |archivedate=2007-03-20 |df= }}</ref> After the Olympics and Paralympics close, the area will be transformed into the largest urban park developed in Europe for more than 150 years, with an area of 500 [[acre]]s (2 km²),<ref name="OlympicParkLegacy">{{cite web |url=http://www.london2012.org/en/ourvision/regeneration/a+new+park.htm |title=A lasting legacy – A new park |work=Our vision |publisher=[[London 2012]] |accessdate=2007-03-30}}</ref> and will be home to the Olympic Medical Institute (OMI), a sports medical and rehabilitation centre.<ref name="OMI">{{cite web |url=http://www.olympics.org.uk/OMI/home.aspx |title=Olympic Medical Institute |accessdate=2007-03-06}}</ref> The bid called for substantial improvement of the [[London Underground]] system, which was supposed to be able to handle the Olympic crowds, and more investment into new Olympic sites throughout the city. London was considered to be the second favourite for the election after Paris, but intense lobbying by the London bid team at the later stages of the bidding process swung the votes in their favour.
On 7 July 2005, the victory celebrations were marred by the [[7 July 2005 London bombings|terrorist attacks]] on London's public transport system. This prompted immediate fears concerning the security of the 2012 Games, to which the IOC and British officials reacted in a reassuring way.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.gamesbids.com/cgi-bin/news/viewnews.cgi?category=1&id=1120759363 |title=London Terrorist Attack Won’t Affect Host City Status Says IOC – Celebration Cancelled |publisher=GamesBids |date=2005-07-07 |accessdate=2007-03-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.gamesbids.com/cgi-bin/news/viewnews.cgi?category=1&id=1120936727 |title=London Will Stage Safe And Secure Games Says Sports Minister |publisher=GamesBids |date=2005-07-09 |accessdate=2007-03-30}}</ref>
===2012 Summer Paralympics=== {{Main|2012 Summer Paralympics}} London won hosting rights to the 2012 Summer Paralympics as part of its successful bid to host the Summer Olympics. The event used many of the Olympic venues.
===2013 Euroleague Final Four=== {{main|2012–13 Euroleague Final Four}} [[Euroleague Basketball Company|Euroleague Basketball]] announced on 12 May 2012 that The O<sub>2</sub> arena would host [[Euroleague Basketball|the league's]] [[Euroleague Final Four|Final Four]] on 10 and 12 May 2013.<ref name="Euroleague Final Four">{{cite press release|url=http://www.euroleague.net/final-four/istanbul-2012/main-page/i/97437/7005 |title=The O2 in London to host the 2013 Turkish Airlines Euroleague Final Four |publisher=Euroleague Basketball |date=12 May 2012 |accessdate=14 April 2013}}</ref>
The contract between Euroleague Basketball and O<sub>2</sub> arena operator [[AEG Live|AEG]] included a mutual option for the venue to host the 2014 Final Four,<ref name="Euroleague Final Four"/> but one or both parties decided not to exercise that option, and the 2014 Final Four was instead awarded to [[Milan]].<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.euroleague.net/news/i/114714/180 |title=Milan, Italy to host 2014 Turkish Airlines Euroleague Final Four |publisher=Euroleague Basketball |date=4 July 2012 |accessdate=18 July 2013}}</ref>
===2013 Women's Champions League and Champions League Finals=== {{main|2013 UEFA Champions League Final|2013 UEFA Women's Champions League Final}} The hosting of the 2011 Champions League Final at the 90,000 Wembley Stadium was deemed such a success, UEFA announced on 16 June 2011 Wembley would host the 2013 final – the first time a stadium has hosted the European Cup final twice in three years.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Champions League final to return to Wembley Stadium in 2013 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/dcunited/champions-league-final-to-return-to-wembley-stadium-in-2013/2011/06/16/AGYZDRXH_story.html |work=The Washington Post |date=16 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011}}</ref> The 2013 final would coincide with the 150th anniversary of [[The Football Association]] – the world's oldest football governing body.
As a part of its successful bid, London was also awarded the 2013 Women's Champions League Final. As in 2011, that match was held two days before the (men's) Champions League Final. This time, [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] hosted the women's final.
===2013 ICC Champions Trophy=== {{Main|2013 ICC Champions Trophy}} Three cities in the United Kingdom, [[London]], [[Cardiff]] and [[Birmingham]], hosted the seventh [[ICC Champions Trophy]], which was intended to be the final edition of that event. The eight major [[Test cricket#Test status|test nations]] competed in the limited overs tournament, with [[India national cricket team|India]] winning.
===2013 Rugby League World Cup=== {{Main|2013 Rugby League World Cup}} Following the success of the [[2008 Rugby League World Cup|2008 World Cup]], the [[RLIF]] officially announced the next tournament to be held in 2013. The UK was favourites to host the sport's most prestigious event, but faced stiff competition from Australia, who had successfully hosted the 2008 competition – the most watched in [[rugby league]]'s history. On 28 July 2009 the RLIF held a meeting in Singapore and, ending months of speculation, announced that the UK would host the 2013 Rugby League World Cup.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/rugbyleague/5925940/United-Kingdom-win-the-race-to-host-2013-Rugby-League-World-Cup.html | work=The Daily Telegraph | location=London | title=United Kingdom win the race to host 2013 Rugby League World Cup | first=Michael | last=Fisher | date=2009-07-28 | accessdate=2010-05-12}}</ref>
===2014 Amlin Challenge Cup and Heineken Cup Finals=== Initially, the 2014 finals of the [[2013–14 Heineken Cup|Heineken Cup]] and [[2013–14 European Challenge Cup#Final|Amlin Challenge Cup]] were scheduled to be held in the [[Paris]] area in [[France]]. However, the [[French Rugby Federation]] pulled out of hosting because of uncertainty over the availability of [[Stade de France]] for the Heineken Cup Final. As a result, the organiser of both competitions, [[European Rugby Cup]], reopened the bidding for both finals (which were awarded in a single package). Bids were received from all three of the Home Nations on the island of Great Britain—[[Rugby Football Union|England]], [[Scottish Rugby Football Union|Scotland]] and [[Welsh Rugby Union|Wales]].<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.ercrugby.com/eng/news/21299.php |title=Three bids for ERC European Club Rugby Finals |publisher=European Rugby Cup |date=20 June 2013 |accessdate=21 June 2013}}</ref>
Ultimately, the finals were awarded to [[Cardiff]], which had most recently hosted the finals in [[#2011 Amlin Challenge Cup and Heineken Cup Finals|2011]]. This was the fifth Heineken Cup Final at Millennium Stadium, and the seventh for the city (two other finals had been held at the [[Cardiff Arms Park#National Stadium|National Stadium]] that previously occupied the Millennium Stadium site).<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/rugby-union/23326691 |title=Cardiff to host Heineken Cup final for a record seventh time |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 July 2013 |accessdate=18 July 2013}}</ref>
Unlike 2011, when the Challenge Cup Final was played at [[Cardiff City Stadium]], the second-tier final was held at [[Cardiff Arms Park]], directly adjacent to Millennium Stadium. This match was the first European final ever played on an artificial surface, as the Arms Park's main tenant, the [[Cardiff Blues]] of [[Pro14|Pro12]], installed a modern artificial pitch for the 2013–14 season.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.espnscrum.com/heineken-cup-2012-13/rugby/story/190895.html |title=Millennium Stadium handed Heineken Cup finale |publisher=''ESPN Scrum'' |date=17 July 2013 |accessdate=18 July 2013}}</ref>
These were the last-ever finals of the Heineken Cup and Amlin Challenge Cup. From 2014–15, these competitions were replaced respectively by the [[European Rugby Champions Cup]] and [[European Rugby Challenge Cup]].
===2014 Tour de France Grand Depart=== The first three stages of the [[2014 Tour de France]] took place in Yorkshire, Cambridgeshire, Essex and London.
===2014 Commonwealth Games=== {{main|2014 Commonwealth Games}} Scotland was the first country to consider hosting the 2014 Commonwealth Games in 2004, with Scottish cities being invited by the [[Commonwealth Games Council for Scotland]] to consider making a bid. In September 2004, Glasgow was announced as the Scottish candidate city over [[Edinburgh]] (which hosted the Games in [[1970 British Commonwealth Games|1970]] and [[1986 Commonwealth Games|1986]], and the inaugural [[Commonwealth Youth Games]] in [[2000 Commonwealth Youth Games|2000]]) following a [[cost-benefit analysis]] by the Commonwealth Games Council for Scotland. The [[Scottish Executive]] under then [[First Minister of Scotland]], [[Jack McConnell]], with the support of the [[Her Majesty's Government|United Kingdom government]]<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/4846034.stm Blair enjoys Games as tour begins]</ref> and all main parties in the [[Scottish Parliament]], formally announced Glasgow's intention to host the games on 16 August 2005.
In March 2006, the bidding process began, with the Glasgow Bid team presenting their case to the Commonwealth Games Federation at the [[2006 Commonwealth Games]] in [[Melbourne]], along with the other confirmed candidate cities; the [[Nigeria]]n capital, [[Abuja]] and [[Halifax Regional Municipality|Halifax]] in [[Canada]]; Halifax later withdrew due to 'unacceptably high cost projections'.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/4154634.stm BBC News – Glasgow launches Commonwealth bid]</ref> In October 2006, the first voting delegates arrived in Glasgow, in order to inspect the city's existing and proposed amenities and facilities. Glasgow announced on 16 January 2007, the 17 sports to be included should its bid be successful.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/scotland/6267309.stm BBC Sport – Glasgow reveals 2014 bid sports ]</ref> Halifax later withdrew its bid on 8 March 2007, following the withdrawal of funding from the municipal government.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/glasgow_and_west/6431603.stm BBC News – Commonwealth bid city pulls out]</ref>
That left Abuja and Glasgow as the remaining bidders, with Abuja seen as a likely favourite due to the basis of its campaign that Africa has never before hosted the Commonwealth Games.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/7086584.stm BBC News – Nigerians keen to host games]</ref> The deadline for formal submission of bids to the Commonwealth Games Federation, in the form of a Candidate City File, was set for May 2007.<ref>[http://www.glasgow2014.com/Our-Bid/The-story-so-far/ Glasgow 2014 – The Story so far] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080624082132/http://www.glasgow2014.com/Our-Bid/The-story-so-far/ |date=2008-06-24 }}</ref> Both bids were highly recommended, though Glasgow's bid team had made use of extensive [[benchmarking]] against the [[2002 Commonwealth Games]] in [[Manchester]] and the 2006 Commonwealth Games in Melbourne and as a result, its bid was deemed technically superior according to the CGF Evaluation Report that was released in September 2007. The Commonwealth Games Evaluation Commission concluded that: "Glasgow has shown it has the ability to stage the 2014 Commonwealth Games to a standard which would continue to enhance the image and prestige of the Games." This put Glasgow ahead in terms of the technical comprehensiveness of its bid.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/glasgow_and_west/6977764.stm BBC News – City ahead in Commonwealth race]</ref>
The final decision on the host city of the 2014 Commonwealth Games was held in [[Colombo]], [[Sri Lanka]] on 9 November 2007 at the Commonwealth Games Federation General Assembly, attended by all 71 [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] Games member associations. Each bid city made a presentation to the General Assembly, the order of which was determined by drawing lots. Glasgow's delegation was led by Louise Martin, chair of the Commonwealth Games Council for Scotland, First Minister [[Alex Salmond]], athlete Jamie Quarry and Leader of [[Glasgow City Council]] Steven Purcell. The presentation also included a promotional film narrated by [[Sean Connery]].<ref>[http://www.glasgow2014.com/Media-Centre/News-releases/TEXTOFTHEPRESENTATIONSFROMSRILANKA.htm Glasgow 2014 Presentation Transcript] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080723121116/http://www.glasgow2014.com/Media-Centre/News-releases/TEXTOFTHEPRESENTATIONSFROMSRILANKA.htm |date=2008-07-23 }}</ref> Abuja's delegation was led by General [[Yakubu Gowon]], head of the Abuja 2014 Commonwealth Games bid team. The CGF members subsequently voted for their preferred candidate in a secret ballot. As there were only two bids, the winner was announced by the CGF President, Mike Fennell, after the first round of voting, with the winner only requiring a simple majority. Celebrations were held at Glasgow's [[Glasgow City Halls|Old Fruitmarket]], where a crowd of over 1,200 had gathered to watch the result live.<ref>[http://www.glasgow2014.com/Media-Centre/wewon/In+pictures+-+the+Old+Fruitmarket+on+NOvember+9.htm The Old Fruitmarket in Pictures]</ref>
===2014 Ryder Cup=== The 2014 [[Ryder Cup]] was held at [[Gleneagles, Scotland|Gleneagles]] in [[Scotland]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/low/golf/1568974.stm|title=Monty congratulates Wales |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2001-09-28 |accessdate=2008-08-03}}</ref>
===2015 European Rugby Challenge Cup and European Rugby Champions Cup Finals=== The inaugural finals of the new European rugby union competitions, the [[European Rugby Champions Cup]] and [[European Rugby Challenge Cup]], were held in London. On 1 May 2015, the [[Twickenham Stoop]] hosted the final of the second-tier [[2014–15 European Rugby Challenge Cup|Challenge Cup]]. The following day, the adjacent [[Twickenham Stadium]] hosted the inaugural [[2015 European Rugby Champions Cup Final|Champions Cup Final]]. Including finals of the former [[Heineken Cup]] and [[European Challenge Cup]], these were the fifth European club rugby finals for each venue.
===2015 World Orienteering Championships=== The 2015 [[World Orienteering Championships]] were hosted by [[Scotland]] and based in [[Inverness]] during August 2015.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-highlands-islands-14579744 | work=BBC News | title=Highlands to host World Orienteering Championships | date=18 August 2011}}</ref> The World Championships were awarded on 18 August 2011 at an [[International Orienteering Federation]] press conference, beating out a bid by Sweden. The championships were previously held in Scotland on two occasions, in 1976 and 1999.
===2015 Rugby World Cup=== {{main|2015 Rugby World Cup}} The [[2015 Rugby World Cup|2015]] [[Rugby World Cup]] was hosted by [[England]]. Their winning bid included the proposed hosting of some games in Cardiff; this was officially ratified by [[World Rugby]], then known as the International Rugby Board (IRB), on 24 May 2011. The Rugby World Cup was awarded on 28 July 2009 following the IRB Executive Board ratifying Rugby World Cup Limited's proposed decision to award the [[2015 Rugby World Cup|2015 World Cup]] to England and the [[2019 Rugby World Cup|2019 World Cup]] to Japan.
===2015 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships=== In May 2011, it was announced that [[Glasgow]] would be the host city of the 2015 edition of the [[World Artistic Gymnastics Championships]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-13501393|title=Glasgow to host 2015 Gymnastic Championships|publisher=BBC News |date=2011-05-23 |accessdate=2011-05-23}}</ref> The 2015 edition was the third to have been staged in the UK, and the first in Scotland, following the Glasgow bid's success over rival pitches from [[Paris]] and [[Orlando, Florida]]. [[The SSE Hydro]], a facility designed and built for the Commonwealth Games that were held in the city a year earlier, was the primary venue for the Championships.
===2016 UCI Track World Championships=== The London VeloPark in the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park, host of the 2012 Summer Olympic track cycling, hosted the world championships in February 2016.<ref>London 2016 Track Cycling Championships official site: http://www.london2016trackcycling.com/</ref>
===2016 World Rugby Under 20 Championship=== On 16 June 2015, [[World Rugby]] announced that the [[2016 World Rugby Under 20 Championship]] (rugby union) would be held in [[Greater Manchester]]. The event used two stadia—[[AJ Bell Stadium]] in [[Salford, Greater Manchester|Salford]] and [[Academy Stadium|Manchester City Academy Stadium]] in [[Manchester]].<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.worldrugby.org/u20/news/69669 |title=England to host World Rugby U20 Championship 2016 |publisher=World Rugby |date=16 June 2015 |accessdate=2 November 2015}}</ref> Since the establishment of the championship's current U20 format in 2008, this was the first time that England hosted and the second for the UK; Wales hosted the 2008 event.
===2016 European Swimming Championships=== During the 2013 LEN Bureau meeting in Barcelona the 2016 European Aquatics Championships was allocated to London. This was the first major international aquatic championship in the Aquatic Centre in the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park since the 2012 Olympic Games.<ref name="LEN 2016 swimming"/>
===2017 European Rugby Challenge Cup and European Rugby Champions Cup Finals=== The 2017 finals of both the European Rugby Champions Cup and European Rugby Challenge Cup were hosted by [[Edinburgh]]'s [[Murrayfield Stadium|Murrayfield]], home to the [[Scottish Rugby Union]] and the [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland national team]]. On 17 June 2015, the organiser of both competitions, [[European Professional Club Rugby]], announced the sites of the 2016 and 2017 finals of both competitions, with the 2016 finals being awarded to [[Parc Olympique Lyonnais|Lyon]], France and the 2017 finals being awarded to Edinburgh.<ref name="2017 EPCR">{{cite press release|url=http://www.epcrugby.com/news/30996.php |title=Lyon to host 2016 Champions Cup and Challenge Cup finals with Edinburgh chosen for 2017 |publisher=European Professional Club Rugby |date=17 June 2015 |accessdate=2 June 2016}}</ref> At that time, Murrayfield was only confirmed as the site of the Champions Cup final,<ref name="2017 EPCR"/> but on 30 March 2016 it was confirmed that Murrayfield would also host the Challenge Cup final.<ref name="2017 Murrayfield">{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/rugby-union/news/12321/10223077/201617-european-champions-cup-and-challenge-cup-finals-set-for-murrayfield-on-may-12-13 |title=2016/17 European Champions Cup and Challenge Cup finals set for Murrayfield on May 12-13 |first=Mike |last=Patterson |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=30 March 2016 |accessdate=2 June 2016}}</ref> The 2017 Champions Cup final was the first at Murrayfield since [[2009 Heineken Cup Final|2009]] and the third overall;<ref name="2017 Murrayfield"/> the 2017 Challenge Cup final was the first ever in Scotland.
===2017 ICC Champions Trophy=== Following the 2013 Champions Trophy, the [[International Cricket Council]] planned to replace the Champions Trophy in the cricketing calendar with the [[ICC World Test Championship]] in [[Test cricket]]. This was the second time the ICC had announced this plan; it had previously intended to launch the Test Championship in 2013, with the [[England and Wales Cricket Board]] (ECB) hosting the inaugural event, but scrapped the original plans in 2011. In 2014, the ICC again cancelled the Test Championship in favour of continuing to hold the Champions Trophy, and the ECB, which had been awarded the 2017 Test Championship, was given hosting rights for the 2017 Champions Trophy as compensation.
===2017 World Para Athletics Championships=== On 19 December 2012, London was announced as host of the [[2017 World Para Athletics Championships|2017 edition]] of the event then known as the IPC Athletics World Championships, using the [[London Stadium|Olympic Stadium]] built for the [[2012 Olympic Games]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/disability-sport/20782283|title=London named host city for 2017 Paralympic World Championships|date=19 December 2012|accessdate=19 December 2012|work=BBC sport}}</ref> By the time of the event, the [[International Paralympic Committee]], which serves as the governing body for disability athletics, had renamed the competition as the [[World Para Athletics Championships]].<ref>{{cite press release|url=https://www.paralympic.org/news/ipc-rebrand-10-sports-it-acts-international-federation |title=The IPC to rebrand the 10 sports it acts as International Federation for |publisher=International Paralympic Committee |date=30 November 2016 |accessdate=13 December 2016}}</ref>
The event was spectacularly successful by the standards of previous editions of these championships. In all, 305,000 tickets were sold for the event—more than were sold for the previous eight editions of these championships combined, and only 10,000 less than [[Rio de Janeiro]] sold for athletics at the [[2016 Summer Paralympics]]. The [[2015 IPC Athletics World Championships]] in [[Qatar]] had total sales of only 15,000.<ref name="Inside the Games">{{cite news|url=https://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1055982/exclusive-london-abandons-plan-to-bid-for-2019-world-para-athletics-championships |title=Exclusive: London abandons plan to bid for 2019 World Para Athletics Championships |first=Duncan |last=Mackay |publisher=''Inside the Games'' |date=29 September 2017 |accessdate=25 May 2018}}</ref>
===2017 IAAF World Athletics Championships=== On 11 March 2011 [[UK Athletics]] announced that they would submit a bid for the [[2017 World Championships in Athletics|2017 Athletics World Championships]], whereby [[London]] would be used to host, using the [[London Stadium|Olympic Stadium]] built for the [[2012 Olympic Games]]. On 11 November 2011 it was announced that the bid was successful.<ref>{{cite web|author=IAAF.org |url=http://www.iaaf.org/aboutiaaf/news/newsid=62905.html |title=London selected to host 2017 IAAF World Championships |publisher=iaaf.org |date=2007-08-25 |accessdate=2011-11-13}}</ref>
===2017 Women's Rugby World Cup=== The [[2017 Women's Rugby World Cup|2017]] [[Women's Rugby World Cup]] was hosted by [[Ireland]]. Rugby union in Ireland is organised on an [[All-Ireland]] basis, with the [[Irish Rugby Football Union]] (IRFU) governing the sport in both the [[Republic of Ireland]] and [[Northern Ireland]]. [[World Rugby]] announced on 13 May 2015 that the IRFU had been awarded the Women's World Cup. The group stage was played in the Republic's capital of [[Dublin]], with all knockout stage and classification matches held in [[Belfast]]. Most of the Belfast matches were held at [[Queen's University Belfast]]; both semi-finals and the final were at [[Ravenhill Stadium]], plus two classification matches that involved [[Ireland women's national rugby union team|the hosts]].<ref name="wrwc 2017 host">{{cite press release|url=http://www.worldrugby.org/news/70650 |title=Ireland to host Women’s Rugby World Cup 2017 |publisher=World Rugby |date=13 May 2015 |accessdate=12 June 2015}}</ref>
===2018 IAAF Athletics World Cup=== On 5 February 2018 British Athletics confirmed that eight of the world’s top athletics nations would compete in the inaugural Athletics World Cup London 2018 at the London Stadium on 14-15 July. <ref>https://www.iaaf.org/news/news/world-cup-2018-london</ref>
==Upcoming events==
===2009–2020 ATP Finals=== The [[ATP Finals]], which ends the [[ATP World Tour]] season in men's tennis, has been hosted at [[The O2 Arena|The O<sub>2</sub> Arena]] in London since 2009. The hosting contract currently runs through the 2020 edition.
===2016–2018 Wheelchair Tennis Masters=== Announced on 3 December 2012, London would be hosting the [[Wheelchair Tennis Masters|NEC Wheelchair Tennis Masters]] for three years starting in 2016 at [[Olympic Park, London]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/tennis/20584783|title=Wheelchair Tennis Masters to be staged at Olympic Park|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=3 December 2012|accessdate=3 December 2012}}</ref>
===2018 Women's Hockey World Cup===
Following an unsuccessful bid to host the 2014 edition of the competition, England was awarded the 2018 Women's Hockey World Cup in November 2013. This will be held at the Lee Valley Hockey and Tennis Centre – host of the 2015 EuroHockey Championships, NEC Tennis Masters from 2016 and also the 2016 Women's Hockey Champions Trophy.
===2019 European Rugby Challenge Cup and European Rugby Champions Cup Finals=== The 2019 finals of both the European Rugby Champions Cup and European Rugby Challenge Cup will be hosted at [[St James' Park]] in [[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle]], normally home to [[Newcastle United F.C.]] On 3 April 2017, the organiser of both competitions, [[European Professional Club Rugby]], announced the sites of the 2018 and 2019 finals of both competitions, with the 2018 finals being awarded to [[San Mamés Stadium (2013)|Bilbao]], Spain and the 2019 finals being awarded to Newcastle.<ref name="2019 EPCR">{{cite press release|url=http://www.epcrugby.com/news/35441.php#.Wwh1plMvzow |title=European club rugby finals to break new ground in 2018 and 2019 |publisher=European Professional Club Rugby |date=3 April 2017 |accessdate=25 May 2018}}</ref> Unlike the announcement of the 2017 finals, for which Murrayfield was initially announced as hosting only the Champions Cup final and only later being confirmed as the Challenge Cup final host, St James' Park was confirmed as hosting both finals.<ref name="2019 EPCR"/> Including finals of the predecessor to the Champions Cup, the Heineken Cup, the 2019 Champions Cup final will be the 15th in Britain and sixth in England, but the first-ever final hosted by an English stadium other than [[Twickenham Stadium|Twickenham]]. As for the Challenge Cup (and ''its'' predecessor, the original European Challenge Cup), this will also be the 15th final staged in the UK, and the 12th in England. St. James' Park will also be the first British stadium to host a Challenge Cup final that at the time was not the regular home to a professional club rugby team.
===2019 Cricket World Cup=== {{main|2019 Cricket World Cup}} The 2019 [[Cricket]] [[Cricket World Cup|World Cup]] will be hosted by [[England and Wales Cricket Board|England and Wales]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/4956010.stm|title=England lands Cricket World Cup|publisher=BBC Sport |date=2006-04-30 |accessdate=2008-08-03}}</ref> This will be the twelfth World Cup competition, and the fifth time it has been held in England, having played host in 1975, 1979, 1983 and 1999.
The hosting rights were awarded in April 2006, after England withdrew from the bidding to host the [[2015 Cricket World Cup]], which was held in [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]]. In turn, those countries had been defeated by [[India]], [[Pakistan]], [[Bangladesh]], and [[Sri Lanka]] for the right to stage the [[2011 Cricket World Cup|2011]] contest.
===2019 Solheim Cup=== {{main|2019 Solheim Cup}} The 2019 [[Solheim Cup]], the women's equivalent to the Ryder Cup, will be hosted by [[Gleneagles Hotel|Gleneagles]] in [[Perth and Kinross]], [[Scotland]]. Gleneagles beat out a rival hosting bid from [[Sweden]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.golf.com/2019-solheim-cup-be-held-gleneagles-scotland |title=2019 Solheim Cup to be Held at Gleneagles in Scotland |agency=Associated Press |publisher=''Golf Magazine'' |date=29 October 2015 |accessdate=25 May 2018}}</ref> This will be the third Solheim Cup to be hosted by the UK, all three by Scotland, but the first since [[2000 Solheim Cup|2000]]. <!-- ==Potential events== -->
==Events speculated==
===Super Bowl=== In 2007, NFL commissioner Roger Goodell stated that "There is a great deal of interest in holding a Super Bowl in London". However, at that time, the earliest Super Bowl London could host would have been [[Super Bowl XLVII]] in 2013.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3065254 |title=Goodell says NFL to look into playing Super Bowl in London |agency=Associated Press |publisher=''ESPN.com'' |date=15 October 2007}}</ref> In 2009, British media reports suggested that London was planning to submit bids for the 2014, 2015 and 2017 Super Bowls, although by that time, Goodell denied any NFL interest in a London bid.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=4130864 |title=Report: London eyes Super Bowl |work=ESPN.com |date=3 May 2009}}</ref> Ultimately, the [[Super Bowl XLVIII|2014 game]] was awarded to the New Meadowlands Stadium, now known as [[MetLife Stadium]], in [[East Rutherford, New Jersey]] (near [[New York City]]) with London not submitting a formal bid. London also did not submit a bid for the [[Super Bowl XLIX|2015 game]], which was awarded to [[University of Phoenix Stadium]] in the [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]] area.<ref name="2015 Super Bowl">{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/7088528/super-bowl-returning-phoenix-arizona-area-2015 |title=Arizona awarded 2015 Super Bowl |agency=Associated Press |work=ESPN.com |date=11 October 2011 |accessdate=11 October 2011}}</ref> The [[Super Bowl LI|2017 game]], which would mark the 50th anniversary of [[Super Bowl I|the first Super Bowl]] (but the 51st game in the series), was eventually awarded to [[NRG Stadium]] (previously Reliant Stadium) in [[Houston]], also without a London bid.<ref>{{cite web|last=Rosenthal|first=Gregg|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap1000000205086/article/san-francisco-awarded-super-bowl-l-houston-lands-li|title=San Francisco awarded Super Bowl L; Houston lands LI|publisher=[[National Football League]]|date=21 May 2013|accessdate=21 May 2013}}</ref>
==Failed/Abandoned Bids==
===2018 Men's Hockey World Cup===
Following an unsuccessful bid to host the 2014 edition of the competition, England won the right to host the Women's World Cup in November 2013, culminating in finals at the Lee Valley Hockey and Tennis Centre, home of the 2012 Summer Paralympic wheelchair tennis competition. The men's World Cup was awarded to India.<ref>http://www.fih.ch/en/news-4386-hockey-world-cup-2018-bidding-workshop-held</ref>
===2018 Summer Youth Olympics=== {{further|Glasgow bid for the 2018 Summer Youth Olympics}}
On 19 September 2011 it was announced that Glasgow would submit to the [[British Olympic Association]] (BOA) a proposal to bid for the 2018 Summer Youth Olympics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/youth_olympic_bids/other_youth_olympic_news/1216135896.html |title=Glasgow To Bid For 2018 Youth Olympics |publisher=GamesBids.com |date= |accessdate=2012-01-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120203035014/http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/youth_olympic_bids/other_youth_olympic_news/1216135896.html |archivedate=2012-02-03 |df= }}</ref> On 22 February 2012 the BOA agreed to put Glasgow forward as the United Kingdom's bidding city for the 2018 Summer Youth Olympics.<ref name="gamesbids.com">[http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/youth_olympic_bids/youth_summer_olympics_2018/1216136106.html Glasgow Great Britain's Candidate For 2018 Youth Olympic Games] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130929134203/http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/youth_olympic_bids/youth_summer_olympics_2018/1216136106.html |date=2013-09-29 }}</ref> In July 2013 they were awarded to Buenos Aires.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olympic.org/news/buenos-aires-elected-as-host-city-for-2018-youth-olympic-games/202222 |title=Buenos Aires elected as Host City for 2018 Youth Olympic Games |publisher=IOC |date=4 July 2013}}</ref>
=== 2018 World Lacrosse Championship === [[Manchester]] was announced in 2013 as the host city for the [[2018 World Lacrosse Championship]] for men.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kinnear|first1=Matt|title=England to Host 2018 Men's World Championships|url=http://www.insidelacrosse.com/article/england-to-host-2018-men-s-world-championships/20783|work=Inside Lacrosse|date=6 August 2013}}</ref> However, the sport's governing body for England, English Lacrosse, withdrew from hosting duties in May 2017, citing what it saw as an unacceptably high level of financial risk.<ref>{{cite press release|url=https://www.englishlacrosse.co.uk/english-lacrosse/statement-regarding-withdrawal-hosting-2018-mens-world-championships-31906/|publisher=English Lacrosse|accessdate=25 May 2017|title=Statement regarding withdrawal from hosting 2018 Men's World Championship}}</ref> The event ultimately took place in [[Netanya]], [[Israel]] between 12 and 21 July 2018.<ref name=filrelease>{{cite press release|url=https://filacrosse.com/israel-to-host-2018-fil-mens-lacrosse-world-championship/|title=Israel to Host 2018 FIL Men’s Lacrosse World Championship|publisher=Federation of International Lacrosse|accessdate=25 May 2017|date=23 May 2017}}</ref>
===2018 FIFA World Cup bid=== {{main|English 2018 FIFA World Cup bid}} It was announced on 2 December 2010 that England's bid was unsuccessful and the 2018 FIFA World Cup would be held in [[Russia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/russia2018/news/newsid=1711839/index.html |title=Russia united for 2018 FIFA World Cup Host Cities announcement |publisher=FIFA |date=2 December 2010}}</ref>
===2017 FIFA Confederations Cup bid=== Failed due to unsuccessful bid to host the 2018 FIFA World Cup.
===UEFA Euro 2016=== In December 2006, the [[Football Association of Wales]] announced it was tentatively considering the possibility of jointly hosting the tournament with the [[Scottish Football Association]]. Scotland, along with the [[Republic of Ireland]], bid for [[Euro 2008]] and there has been much discussion over whether the nation should consider a solo bid for Euro 2016. The entrance into government of the [[Scottish National Party]] (SNP) had previously boosted the hopes of such an outcome.
Ultimately it was announced on 9 March 2009 that Scotland and Wales, who had planned to bid together, decided the cost of staging the event was too great. Factors sited were principally the dire economic situation and the fact that 2016 would see the tournament expand to 24 teams from 16, greatly increasing the cost of hosting.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/internationals/7918050.stm | work=BBC News | title=Wales and Scotland ditch Euro bid | date=2009-03-02 | accessdate=2010-05-12}}</ref>
===2014 Men's and Women's Hockey World Cup=== [[London]] bid to host the [[Hockey World Cup|men's]] and [[Women's Hockey World Cup|women's]] versions of the Hockey World Cup in 2014. The bid would have been only the second time both events have been held simultaneously and was planned to centre around the [[Olympic Hockey Centre (London)|Olympic Hockey Centre]], built for the [[2012 Olympic Games]], and would have been the first international event held at a 'legacy facility' in the Olympic Park after the London Olympics. Boxing promoter [[Frank Warren (promoter)|Frank Warren]] was brought in by [[England Hockey]] to help with the bid.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/hockey/9105482.stm |title=England table bid for 2014 Hockey World Cups |publisher=''BBC.co.uk'' |date=19 October 2010}}</ref> On 11 November 2010, it was announced the Netherlands had won the bid.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/hockey/9181810.stm|title=Olympic Park loses bid to host 2014 Hockey World Cups|last=Williams|first=Ollie|date=11 November 2010|work=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=11 November 2010}}</ref>
===2015 IAAF World Athletics Championships=== [[London]] submitted a bid to the [[IAAF]] to host the 2015 World Championships in 2010, however due to the uncertain future of the [[London Stadium|Olympic stadium]] at the time, the bid was moved to the 2017 World championships, leaving only [[Beijing]] in the race. The event was accordingly held in The [[Beijing National Stadium|Bird's Nest Stadium]], the athletics venue for the 2008 Olympic Games.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/athletics/9156858.stm | work=BBC News | title=London pulls out of 2015 Worlds | date=4 November 2010}}</ref>
===2018 Gay Games=== London was one of three cities shortlisted to host the 2018 edition of the Gay Games, alongside Paris and Limerick. Venues would have included many of those used in the 2012 Summer Olympics, including those in the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park, as well as The O2 Arena and SouthBank Centre. The Games were awarded to Paris.<ref>http://gaygames.org</ref>
===2019 World Para Athletics Championships=== Following the success of the 2017 World Para Athletics Championships, UK Athletics announced that it would submit a bid to host the event again in [[2019 World Para Athletics Championships|2019]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/disability-sport/40703217|title=World Para-athletics Championships 2019 could be back in London|date=24 July 2017|publisher=BBC}}</ref> London was competing against [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia]] for hosting rights, with a bidding deadline of 30 September 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/more-sports/other-sports/news/29877/10959280/london-consider-2019-world-para-athletics-championships-bid|title=London consider 2019 World Para Athletics Championships bid|date=24 July 2017|publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref> However, the day before the bidding deadline, London abandoned the 2019 bid, citing scheduling issues and a lack of funding to support the bid.<ref name="Inside the Games"/> With Kuala Lumpur also pulling out, bidding was reopened, and the event was ultimately awarded to [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]].<ref>{{cite press release|title=Dubai to host 2019 World Para Athletics Championships|url=https://www.paralympic.org/news/dubai-host-2019-world-para-athletics-championships|publisher=International Paralympic Committee|accessdate=12 June 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20130228114959/http://www.london2012.com/ London Summer Olympics 2012 Official site] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080731205144/http://www.rydercupwales2010.com/ Ryder Cup Wales 2010 Official site] * [http://www.glasgow2014.com Glasgow 2014 Commonwealth Games Official site] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100607002522/http://www.england2018bid.com/ England 2018 FIFA World Cup official bid site]
