revision.comment: Robot - Moving category 1960 Winter Olympics venues to [[:Category:Venues of the 1960 Winter Olympics]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 October 19]].
revision.text:
'''McKinney Creek Stadium''' was a temporary [[ski stadium]] located at [[Tahoma, California]], in the [[United States]]. Built in 1959, it was used for [[cross-country skiing]], [[Nordic combined]] and [[biathlon]] at the [[1960 Winter Olympics]] in [[Squaw Valley, Placer County, California|Squaw Valley]].
==History== As Squaw Valley was an undeveloped area at the time of being awarded the Olympics, the organizing committee was free to build a tailor-made Olympic resort.<ref>Squaw Valley Organizing Committee: 33</ref> The organizing committee originally intended to house all events in Squaw Valley proper, but real estate developments in Squaw Valley made this difficult. In 1958 the organizing committee therefore decided to move all cross-country and biathlon events to McKinney Creek.<ref name=s115>Squaw Valley Organizing Committee: 115</ref>
Rolf Gerlofsen had surveyed the area in March 1957, and work on the biathlon tracks and facilities was undertaken and completed during the summer of 1958. It was the first time that pull targets were installed for a biathlon competition.<ref name=s118>Squaw Valley Organizing Committee: 118</ref>
Work on the stadium began in August 1959.<ref name=s109>Squaw Valley Organizing Committee: 109</ref> Plans for the tracks were approved by the [[International Ski Federation]]'s Knut Korsvold and [[Sigge Bergman]], after which construction of the trails could start in the summer 1959. Trial events were undertaken in 1959, in which it was found that mechanical track preparation was more efficient than manual, given that there was at least 45 centimeters (18 in) of snow.<ref name=s115 /> After the Olympics, the stadium was dismounted.
==Facilities== McKinney Creek Stadium was located immediately off [[California State Route 89]], 19 kilometers (12 mi) south of Squaw Valley. It was the only venue to not be located in the ski resort itself.<ref name=s115 /> The stadium was {{convert|250|m|sp=us}} long and between {{convert|34|and|45|m|sp=us}} wide. [[Bleacher]]s were erected on one side of the finish line with space for 1,000 spectators and 200 press officers. A 16 by 4 meter (54 by 13 ft) [[scoreboard]] was built behind the finish line, which at any given time showed the latest times and the ten best results. Flags for all participating nations at the games were hoisted along the stadium.<ref name=s109 />
The main building was the Timing Building, which consisted of a calculations room, a communications room, an office for the race secretary in addition to areas for timing staff and equipment. The upper section was used by the public announcer and featured sixteen radio booths. Two 6 by 15 meter (20 by 48 ft) [[Quonset hut]]s with a total sixteen rooms were built for competitors for waxing, resting and changing. Lack of water caused the stadium to lack showers. An identically sized Quonset hut was built for administration personnel and course preparation works. A larger 6 by 20 meter (20 by 64 ft) Quonset hut was built for the press, which included typewriters, [[teletype machine]]s, telephones and a [[darkroom]].<ref name=s109 />
The biathlon course had four shooting ranges along the {{convert|20|km|sp=us|adj=on}} course. A {{convert|200|m|sp=us|adj=on}} range was installed at {{convert|6.5|km|sp=us}}, a {{convert|250|m|sp=us|adj=on}} range at {{convert|9.5|km|sp=us}}, a {{convert|150|m|sp=us|adj=on}} range at {{convert|12.5|km|sp=us}} and a {{convert|100|m|sp=us|adj=on}} range at {{convert|15|km|sp=us}}. The ranges had 15 pull-type targest with a "sleeve and plunger" system with five recharges. This allowed up to 75 participants in the race. An additional practacing range was built in the Squaw Valley–Deer Park area, in addition to the {{convert|250|m|sp=us|adj=on}} range being available for training. Coordination of the shooting station was undertaken by four groups of twenty men from the [[United States Air Force Rifle School]]. First aid stations were installed at each range.<ref name=s118 />
Track preparation was undertaken every evening before the events. Crews were assigned to sections of tracks, with the responsibility of skiing the courses one and a half hours before start, policing the section and removing markers after the event. Each event was color-coded and all marking and material for each event used the colors for visual identification. Training tracks were available in the McKinney Park area and the Squaw Valley–Deer Park area. Both official electronic and unofficial manual timing was used. Interval times were taken at {{convert|5|km|sp=us|adj=on}} intervals and phoned to the stadium.<ref name=s115 />
==Events== Cross-country skiing consisted of [[cross-country skiing at the 1960 Winter Olympics|six events]]—four for men and two for women, including a [[relay race]] for both genders. The [[cross-country skiing at the 1960 Winter Olympics – Men's 30 kilometre|men's 30 kilometer]] saw a [[Sweden at the 1960 Winter Olympics|Swedish]] double won by [[Sixten Jernberg]] ahead of [[Rolf Ramgard]].<ref name=s116>Squaw Valley Organizing Committee: 116</ref> In the [[cross-country skiing at the 1960 Winter Olympics – Men's 15 kilometre|men's 15 kilometer]], Jernberg finished second after [[Norway at the 1960 Winter Olympics|Norway]]'s [[Hakon Brusveen]].<ref name=s115 /> The [[cross-country skiing at the 1960 Winter Olympics – Men's 4 × 10 kilometre relay|men's 4 × 10 kilometer relay]] saw [[Finland at the 1960 Winter Olympics|Finland]] win ahead of Norway and the Soviet Union. The [[United States at the 1960 Winter Olympics|United States]] finished last of the eleven teams.<ref name=s117>Squaw Valley Organizing Committee: 117</ref> The final men's race was the [[cross-country skiing at the 1960 Winter Olympics – Men's 50 kilometre|men's 50 kilometer]], which saw a Finish double with [[Kalevi Hämäläinen]] win ahead of [[Veikko Hakulinen]] followed by three SWedes.<ref name=s116 /> The men's relay saw the largest crowd, of 3,000 spectators.<ref name=s115 />
The [[cross-country skiing at the 1960 Winter Olympics – Women's 10 kilometre|women's 10 kilometer]] saw the [[Soviet Union at the 1960 Winter Olympics|Soviet Union]] win the four top positions, with [[Maria Gusakova]] winning gold and [[Lyubov Kozyreva (cross-country skier)|Lyubov Kozyreva]] winning silver. Five teams entered the [[cross-country skiing at the 1960 Winter Olympics – Women's 3 × 5 kilometre relay|women's 3 × 5 kilometer relay]]. Despite the Soviet dominance in the individual race, Sweden was successful at beating the Soviet Union, ahead of Finland, [[Poland at the 1960 Winter Olympics|Poland]] and [[Germany at the 1960 Winter Olympics|Germany]].<ref name=s117 />
The ski jumping part of the [[Nordic combined at the 1960 Winter Olympics|Nordic combined]] took place at [[Papoose Peak Jumps]] in Squaw Valley.<ref name=s104>Squaw Valley Organizing Committee: 104</ref> Germany's [[Georg Thoma]] won the ski jumping event and succeeded at defending the gold through the 15 kilometer cross-country race. The Soviet Union's [[Dmitriy Kochkin]] finished second after the jumps, but was relegated to fifth after the cross-country event, with Norway's [[Tormod Knutsen]] taking silver.<ref name=s106>Squaw Valley Organizing Committee: 106</ref>
The 1960 Winter Olympics saw the debut of biathlon. Thirty competitors from nine nations entered [[Biathlon at the 1960 Winter Olympics|the 20 kilometer race]], which was undertaken with one-minute interval start.<ref name=s118 /> The race was won by [[Klas Lestander]] of Sweden ahead of [[Finland at the 1960 Winter Olympics|Finland]]'s [[Antti Tyrvainen]] and four Soviet biathletes.<ref name=s120>Squaw Valley Organizing Committee: 120</ref>
==External links== *[http://www.waymarking.com/waymarks/WMHNMD_Location_of_McKinney_Creek_Stadium_Olympic_Winter_Games_1960 Location of McKinney Creek Stadium] on Waymarking.com *[https://web.archive.org/web/20131202220051/http://www.gotahoenorth.com/skiing-and-boarding/cross-country-skiing/sugar-pine-point-state-park Sugar Pine Point State Park Cross-country Ski Map] on Go Tahoe North *[http://goo.gl/maps/ytjEN McKinney Creek Stadium] on Google Maps
==References== ;Bibliography * {{cite book |last1=Squaw Valley Organizing Committee|title=VIII Olympic Winter Games Squaw Valley, California 1960 Final Report |publisher=California Olympic Commission|url=http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1960/1960w.pdf |format=PDF |year=1960 |location=Squaw Valley |accessdate=20 June 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629132958/http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1960/1960w.pdf |archivedate=29 June 2011 |deadurl=no}}
;Notes {{reflist|2}}

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2017}} [[File:Patrick Kerney sacks Aaron Rodgers.jpg|thumb|279x279px|Green Bay quarterback [[Aaron Rodgers]] being sacked by Seattle defensive end [[Patrick Kerney]].]] In [[American football]] and [[Canadian football]], a '''sack''' occurs when the [[quarterback]] (or another offensive player acting as a passer) is [[tackle (football move)|tackled]] behind the [[line of scrimmage]] before he can throw a [[forward pass]], when the quarterback is tackled behind the line of scrimmage in the "[[passing pocket|pocket]]" and his intent is unclear, or when a passer runs out of bounds behind the line of scrimmage due to defensive pressure.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://fs.ncaa.org/Docs/stats/Stats_Manuals/Football/2011ez.pdf |title= 2011 Football Statisticians Manual, p. 17 |publisher=NCAA |access-date=October 15, 2017}}</ref> This often occurs if the opposing team's [[defensive team|defensive line]], [[linebacker]]s or [[defensive backs]] are able to apply '''pass pressure''' (also called a '''pass rush''') to quickly get past [[blocking (American football)|blocking]] players of the [[offensive team]] (the quarterback's protection), or if the quarterback is unable to find a back to hand the ball off to or an available [[eligible receiver]] (including [[wide receiver]]s, [[running back]]s and [[tight end]]s) to catch the ball, allowing the defense a longer opportunity to tackle the quarterback.
Performing a sack is advantageous for the defending team as the offence loses a [[Down (gridiron football)|down]], and the line of scrimmage retreats several yards.<ref name=":0" /> Even better for the defense is a sack causing the quarterback to [[fumble]] the ball at or behind the line of scrimmage; this is also known as a '''strip sack''' and can result in a [[Turnover (gridiron football)|turnover]] if the defense manages to obtain the ball. A quarterback that is pressured but avoids a sack can still be adversely affected by being forced to '''hurry'''.
In the [[National Football League]] (NFL), it is possible to record a sack for zero yards. The QB must pass the statistical line of scrimmage to avoid the sack. If a passer is sacked in his own end zone, the result is a [[Safety (gridiron football score)|safety]] and the defending team is awarded two points, unless the football is fumbled and either recovered in the end zone by the defense for a touchdown or recovered by either team outside the end zone.
==Statistical record rules== To be considered a sack the quarterback must intend to throw a forward pass. If the play is designed for the quarterback to rush (run) the ball, any loss is subtracted from the quarterback's rushing total (and the play is ruled a [[tackle for loss]] as opposed to a sack). If the quarterback's intent is not obvious, statisticians use certain criteria, such as the offensive line blocking scheme, to decide. Unique situations where a loss reduces a quarterback's rushing total (not a sack) are "[[Quarterback kneel|kneel downs]]" (used to run time off the game clock). [[File:Everson Griffen Aaron Rodgers sack.jpg|thumb|Rodgers sacked by Everson Griffen.]] A player will receive credit for half of a sack when multiple players contribute to the sacking of a quarterback, even if more than two players contributed.
In the [[National Football League|NFL]] yards lost on the play are added as negative yardage to the team's passing totals; however, the quarterback's individual passing total stats remains unchanged.<ref>http://www.nflgsis.com/gsis/documentation/stadiumguides/guide_for_statisticians.pdf</ref> [[college football|NCAA]] continues to subtract sack yardage from individual rushing totals.
==History== [[File:Cougars on offense at BYU at Air Force 2010-09-11.jpg|alt=|thumb|A [[BYU Cougars football|BYU]] quarterback being sacked by [[Air Force Falcons football|Air Force]].]] The term "sack" was first popularized by [[Pro Football Hall of Fame|Hall of Fame]] defensive end [[Deacon Jones]] in the 1960s, who felt that a sack devastated the offense in the same way that a city was devastated when it was sacked.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jones, NFL coiner of 'sack the quarterback,' dies at 74|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/06/04/us/sport-deacon-jones-death/index.html|work=CNN|accessdate=June 5, 2013|date=June 4, 2013}}</ref>
According to former NFL coach [[Marv Levy]], it was [[Washington Redskins]] coach [[George Allen (American football coach)|George Allen]] who actually coined the term when referring to [[Dallas Cowboys]] quarterback [[Craig Morton]].<ref>http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2013/06/16/levy-explains-how-deacon-jones-came-up-with-sack/</ref> Allen purportedly stated before a game, "Before we play those Dallas Cowboys, we’re going to take that Morton salt and pour him into a sack."
Prior to "sack", the term "dump" was often used, and the NFL's statistical office recorded all sacks under "dumping the passer".<ref name=":0">{{cite news|title=Sack or Dump: To Quarterback It's All Downhill|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1499&dat=19751107&id=72kaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=KikEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5990,3948674|accessdate=June 5, 2013|newspaper=The Milwaukee Journal|date=November 7, 1975}}</ref>
The NFL only began to keep track of times passers lost yardage in 1961<ref>[http://www.nfl.com/history/randf/records/indiv/passing NFL Records]</ref> and no credit was given to the defensive player responsible until 1982.<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.nfl.com/history/randf/records/indiv/sacks NFL Records]</ref> Researcher John Turney of the [[Pro Football Researchers Association]] estimated that Jones recorded 173½ sacks in his career.<ref name=branch>{{cite news |last=Branch |first=John |title=Unofficially, Sack Record Doesn't Add Up |date=November 4, 2006 |newspaper=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/04/sports/football/04giants.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6W4mWuYGm?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/04/sports/football/04giants.html?_r=0 |archivedate=February 3, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
Controversial NFL rule changes made for the [[2018 NFL season|2018 season]] prohibit tacklers landing on the quarterback after making a sack, with the punishment being a [[roughing the passer]] penalty.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sbnation.com/nfl/2018/9/27/17911444/nfl-roughing-the-passer-penalty-explanation-clay-matthews|title=The NFL’s controversial new roughing the passer rule, explained in a 3-minute read|work=SBNation.com|access-date=2018-09-28}}</ref>
==Pass pressure== [[File:Nate Longshore under pressure AFB 071231-F-7061J-010.JPEG|thumb|A quarterback under pressure.]] Of all forms of defensive pressure against the opposition's passer, sacks provide the most immediate impact by ending the offensive play.<ref name=schatz>{{cite news|last=Schatz|first=Aaron|title=Examining the art of the hurry|date=June 1, 2010|work=ESPN.com|url=http://insider.espn.go.com/nfl/insider/news/story?id=5238886|accessdate=February 2, 2014}}{{subscription required}}</ref> However, quarterbacks sometimes avoid a sack by throwing an [[incomplete pass]] or risking an [[interception]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Long|first1=Howie|last2=Czarnecki|first2=John|title=Football For Dummies|year=2011|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|page=166|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pbduM8Jyc34C&lpg=PA389&dq=quarterback%20hurry%20dummies&pg=PA166#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=February 2, 2014}}</ref> According to [[Football Outsiders]], a quarterback hurry is the most common form of pass pressure. In the [[2009 NFL season]], there were 1,106 sacks and 3,268 hurries, and a hurried quarterback generally averaged fewer yards per pass play compared to the average pass play.<ref name=schatz/>
==NFL Records == These records are from 1982 onwards, the year the NFL started officially recording sacks.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> *NFL single-season sacks: 22.5, [[Michael Strahan]], 2001{{efn|[[Deacon Jones]] had 26 sacks in 14 games in the 1967 season, and 24 sacks in 14 games in the 1968 season. However, as sacks were not officially recorded by the NFL at that point, [[Michael Strahan]] is credited with the single-season record.}} *NFL career sacks: 200, [[Bruce Smith (defensive end)|Bruce Smith]], 1985–2003 *NFL single-game sacks: 7, [[Derrick Thomas]], November 11, 1990 vs. Seattle Seahawks *NFL sacks, rookie season: 14.5, [[Jevon Kearse]], 1999{{efn|[[Al "Bubba" Baker]] had 23 sacks in his rookie 1978 season. However, as sacks were not officially recorded by the NFL at that point, [[Jevon Kearse]] is credited with the single-season rookie record.}} *NFL seasons with 20 or more sacks: 2, [[J. J. Watt]], 2012 & 2014<ref>{{cite news|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/nfl-shutdown-corner/j-j--watt-becomes-only-two-time-20-sack-player--does-so-on-safety-210051599.html|title=J.J. Watt becomes only two-time 20-sack player, does so on safety |accessdate=February 1, 2015 |date=December 28, 2015|work=Yahoo! Sports|last=Edholm|first=Eric}}</ref> *NFL most consecutive games recording a sack (team): 69, [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers|Tampa Bay]], 1999–2003 *NFL career sacks taken: 525, [[Brett Favre]], 1991–2010<ref>[https://www.pro-football-reference.com/leaders/pass_sacked_career.htm NFL Career Sacked Leaders – Pro-Football-Reference.com]</ref> *NFL single-season sacks taken: 76, [[David Carr (American football)|David Carr]], 2002<ref>[https://www.pro-football-reference.com/leaders/pass_sacked_single_season.htm NFL Single-Season Sacked Leaders – Pro-Football-Reference.com]</ref> *NFL game sacks taken: 12, [[Warren Moon]], September 29, 1985 and [[Donovan McNabb]], September 30, 2007<ref>[https://www.pro-football-reference.com/leaders/pass_sacked_single_game.htm NFL Single Game Sacked Leaders – Pro-Football-Reference.com]</ref> *NFL game more sacks taken than yards passing: 5 sacks and 4 yards passing, [[Colin Kaepernick]] on December 4, 2016.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bieler|first1=Des|title=Colin Kaepernick sets NFL record for quarterback futility in loss to Bears|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2016/12/04/colin-kaepernick-sets-nfl-record-for-quarterback-futility-in-loss-to-bears/|work=The Washington Post|date=December 4, 2016}}</ref> *NFL [[Super Bowl]] most sacks in a single game, 12 [[Super Bowl 50|Carolina vs. Denver, 50]] (7 by Denver, 5 by Carolina) *NFL [[Super Bowl]] most sacks by a player in a single game, 3{{efn|[[L. C. Greenwood]] had 4 sacks in [[Super Bowl X]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/nfl/super/superbowl-x-plays.htm |title=Super Bowl X play-by-play |publisher=[[USA TODAY]] |accessdate=April 5, 2013 |date=January 11, 2002}}</ref> However, as sacks were not officially recorded by the NFL at that point, [[Reggie White]], [[Darnell Dockett]], [[Kony Ealy]], and [[Grady Jarrett]] are credited with the Super Bowl record for most sacks in a single game (3).}} :*[[Reggie White]] – [[Super Bowl XXXI|Green Bay vs. New England, XXXI]] :*[[Darnell Dockett]] – [[Super Bowl XLIII|Arizona vs. Pittsburgh, XLIII]] :*[[Kony Ealy]] – [[Super Bowl 50|Carolina vs. Denver, 50]] :*[[Grady Jarrett]] – [[Super Bowl LI|Atlanta vs. New England, LI]]
*NFL [[Super Bowl]] most sacks, career ''(sacks compiled since XVII)'' :*4.5, [[Charles Haley]] – 5 games [[San Francisco 49ers|San Francisco]] [[Super Bowl XXIII|XXIII]], [[Super Bowl XXIV|XXIV]], [[Dallas Cowboys|Dallas]] [[Super Bowl XXVII|XXVII]], [[Super Bowl XXVIII|XXVIII]], [[Super Bowl XXX|XXX]]
==See also== * [[List of National Football League annual sacks leaders]] * [[List of National Football League career sacks leaders]] * ''[[The Blind Side: Evolution of a Game]]'' – non-fiction book by [[Michael Lewis (author)|Michael Lewis]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Select Sport | logo = | type = Private limited company | foundation = 1947 | founder = [[Eigil Nielsen (footballer, born 1918)|Eigil Nielsen]] | location_city = [[Glostrup Municipality|Glostrup]], [[Copenhagen]] | location_country = [[Denmark]] | key_people = Peter Knap <small>([[chief executive officer|CEO]])</small>, Preben Kønig <small>([[Chairman]])</small> | industry = [[sports equipment]] | services = | revenue = | net_income = | num_employees = | homepage = http://www.select-sport.com/da/ | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Select Sport A.S.''' is a [[denmark|Danish]] [[sports equipment]] manufacturer based in [[Glostrup]], [[Denmark]].
As of 2008, Select provides the [[Danish Football Association]] with footballs, and also several clubs in the [[Danish Superliga|Danish]], [[Belgian Pro League|Belgian]] and [[Russian Premier League|Russian]] top football leagues use Select balls.
Select balls are used in the [[olympic games|Olympic]] [[handball]] games, as well as in the [[World Men's Handball Championship|World Championship]] and in the [[Danish Handball League|Danish]], [[Elitserien (men's handball)|Swedish]] and [[Liga ASOBAL|Spanish]] men's handball leagues, among others.
The company's U.S. subsidiary, Select Sport America, has contracts to supply soccer balls for the [[United Soccer Leagues]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uslsoccer.com/news_article/show/864128?referrer_id=2333971 |title=United Soccer Leagues Announces New Partnership with Select|publisher=United Soccer League (USL) |date=December 6, 2017 |accessdate=December 6, 2017}}</ref> [[National Premier Soccer League]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npsl.com/news_article/show/908527?referrer_id=1510764 |title=Select Named Official Match Ball Sponsor of the NPSL|publisher=National Premier Soccer League (NPSL) |date=April 16, 2018 |accessdate=April 16, 2018}}</ref> [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics|NAIA]], several [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[NCAA Division II|Division II]] and [[NCAA Division III|Division III]] conferences, and state high school federations in [[Kentucky High School Athletic Association|Kentucky]] and [[Wisconsin Interscholastic Athletic Association|Wisconsin]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.selectsportamerica.com/sponsor/ |title=Sponsor |publisher=Select Sport America |accessdate=March 19, 2015}}</ref>
==History== It was founded in 1947 by [[Eigil Nielsen (footballer born 1918)|Eigil Nielsen]],<ref>[http://www.select.dk/script/site/page.asp?artid=142 SELECT - The origin] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120809101535/http://www.select.dk/script/site/page.asp?artid=142 |date=2012-08-09 }}, Select.dk {{da icon}}, retrieved June 10, 2012</ref> the former goalkeeper of the [[Denmark national football team|Danish national football team]].
In the late 1950s or early 1960s, Select manufactured and marketed the first 32-panel [[soccer ball]].<ref>{{cite web|title=SELECT Since 1947|url=http://www.selectsportamerica.com/history/|publisher=SELECT|accessdate=July 21, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150702050750/http://www.selectsportamerica.com/history/|archivedate=July 2, 2015|df=}}</ref><ref name="soccerballworldhistory2">[http://www.soccerballworld.com/Historypg2.htm The history of the soccer ball], Soccerballworld.com {{en icon}}, retrieved May 29, 2008</ref> Based loosely on the [[geodesic dome]] designs of [[Buckminster Fuller|R. Buckminster Fuller]],<ref name="soccerballworldhistory2" /> it consisted of 12 black [[pentagon]]s and 20 white [[hexagon]]s. The 32 panel configuration became the world standard for several decades. Select was also the first manufacturer of footballs without exterior lacing.<ref>[http://www.select-sport.com/script/site/page.asp?artid=61&cat_id=58 About SELECT] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080602085129/http://www.select-sport.com/script/site/page.asp?artid=61&cat_id=58 |date=2008-06-02 }}, Select-sport.com {{da icon}}, retrieved May 27, 2008</ref>
==Sponsorships== '''Select Sport''' is the official supplier and sponsor of numerous [[association football]] teams, players and associations, including:
===Football=== ====National teams==== * {{fb|GRL}} (Since September 2018) ====Associations==== Select is official ball supplier for the following football leagues/associations: * {{flagicon|BEL}} [[Belgian First Division A|Jupiler Pro League]] * {{flagicon|DEN}} [[Danish Superliga|ALKA Superliga]] * {{flagicon|DEN}} [[Danish 1st Division|NordicBet Liga]] * {{flagicon|DEN}} [[Denmark national football team]] * {{flagicon|FIN}} [[Veikkausliiga]] * {{flagicon|ISL}} [[Úrvalsdeild]] * {{flagicon|ITA}} [[Serie A (women's football)]] * {{flagicon|NOR}} [[Eliteserien (football)|Eliteserien]] * {{flagicon|NOR}} [[Toppserien]] * {{flagicon|SWE}} [[Allsvenskan]] * {{flagicon|SWE}} [[Superettan]] * {{flagicon|UKR}} [[Ukrainian Cup]] * {{flagicon|USA}} [[United Soccer Leagues]] ([[United Soccer League|USL]], [[USL League One]], [[USL League Two]], [[Super Y-League]]) * {{flagicon|USA}} [[National Premier Soccer League]]
====Club teams==== *{{flagicon|DEN}} [[Aarhus Fremad]] *{{flagicon|DEN}} [[BK Avarta|Avarta]] *{{flagicon|DEN}} [[IF Skjold Birkerød|Birkerød]] *{{flagicon|DEN}} [[Gentofte-Vangede Idrætsforening]] *{{flagicon|KEN}} [[Kakamega Homeboyz F.C.|Kakamega Homeboyz]] *{{flagicon|NOR}} [[Hønefoss BK|Hønefoss]] *{{flagicon|NOR}} [[Moss FK|Moss]] *{{flagicon|NOR}} [[Sarpsborg 08 FF|Sarpsborg]] (Since 2015) *{{flagicon|NOR}} [[Tromsø IL|Tromsø]] (Since 2016) *{{flagicon|OMN}} [[Fanja SC|Fanja]] (Since 2016) *{{flagicon|SWE}} [[ IK Brage|Brage]] (Since 2015) *{{flagicon|SWE}} [[GAIS]]
===Handball=== ====National teams==== *{{hb|AUT}} *{{hb|CHI}} *{{hb|FRO}} *{{hb|Portugal}}
====Club teams==== *{{flagicon|DEN}} [[GOG Håndbold|GOG]] *{{flagicon|GER}} [[VfL Gummersbach]]
===Deaf Futsal===
====Club teams==== *{{flagicon|UAE}} [[Abu Dhabi Club|Abu Dhabi]] (Since 2016)
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.select-sport.com/ Official website] {{en icon}} {{da icon}} * [http://www.selectsportamerica.com/ Official USA website] * [http://www.select.dk/ Unofficial website] {{da icon}}

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Sharp Gymnasium | logo_image = | image =Sharp Gymnasium, Houston Baptist University.JPG | image_size =275px | location = 7502 Fondren Road
[[Houston, Texas]] 77074 | fullname = Frank and Lucille Sharp Physical Education Building | coordinates = {{Coord|29|41|42|N|95|31|01|W|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = 1963 | opened = 1964 | expanded = | renovated = 1994, 2011 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Houston Baptist University]] | operator = [[Houston Baptist University]] | surface = Multi-surface | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | tenants = [[Houston Baptist Huskies men's basketball]]
[[Houston Baptist Huskies women's basketball]]
[[Houston Baptist Huskies women's volleyball]] | seating_capacity = 1,000{{cite web|title=Quick Facts|url=http://www.hbuhuskies.com/documents/2015/11/4/2015_16_HBU_MBB_Quick_Facts.pdf|publisher=Houston Baptist University Athletics|accessdate=September 4, 2016}} | website = {{url | http://www.hbuhuskies.com/sports/2011/9/21/Facilities.aspx}} }} The '''Frank and Lucille Sharp Gymnasium''' is a 1,000-seat multi-purpose arena in [[Houston, Texas]]. It was built in 1963 and is home to the [[Houston Baptist University]] Huskies basketball and volleyball teams.{{cite web|title=Facilities|url=http://www.hbuhuskies.com/sports/2011/9/21/Facilities.aspx|publisher=Houston Baptist University Athletics|accessdate=September 4, 2016}} Sharp Gymnasium served as the temporary home court for the 2007-08 Rice Owls women's team for nine home games while [[Rice University]] renovated Autry Court to [[Tudor Fieldhouse]].{{cite web|title=Women's Basketball 2007-2008 Schedule|url=http://www.riceowls.com/sports/w-baskbl/sched/rice-w-baskbl-sched.html|publisher=Rice University Athletics|accessdate=September 4, 2016}}{{cite web|title=Autry Court renovation ready to roll|url=http://www.riceowls.com/genrel/071707aac.html|publisher=Rice University Athletics|accessdate=September 4, 2016|date=July 17, 2007}} == Gallery == {{gallery |title= |width=250 |height=180 |lines=3 |align=center |File:HBU Basketball CIMG8372.JPG |alt1=Jumpball |A [[jump ball]] begins a men's basketball game at Sharp Gymnasium on February 18, 2008 between against the [[Dallas Christian College|Dallas Christian Crusaders]]. |File:Sharp Gym CIMG8287.JPG |alt3=Crowd after the game |A crowd gathers on the basketball court at Sharp Gymnasium after a men's basketball game between the Houston Baptist Huskies and Bacone Warriors on February 9, 2008. }} ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == venues completed in 1964]] [[Category:1964 establishments in Texas]] {{Texas-sports-venue-stub}} {{Houston-stub}}

{{redirect|FIAT Torino|the current club in the [[Lega Basket Serie A]]|Auxilium Pallacanestro Torino}} {{refimprove|date=August 2017}} [[File:Sisport (logo).jpg|thumb|Sisport logo]]
'''Sisport''' is a women's basketball team during the 1970s and 1980s in [[Turin]], Italy.
==History== ''Gruppo Sportivo FIAT'' (''G.S. FIAT'') was founded in 1922 by employees of the [[Fiat S.p.A.|eponymous automobile manufacturer]] the city of Turin is still associated with.<ref name="Sisport">{{cite web|title=Chi siamo (Who we are)|url=https://www.sisport.life/it/chisiamo/Pages/chi-siamo.aspx/it/chisiamo/Pages/chi-siamo.aspx|work=sisportfiat.it|language=Italian}}</ref> Since 1978, it has first known as ''Sisport Fiat''<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.archiviolastampa.it/component/option,com_lastampa/task,search/mod,libera/action,viewer/Itemid,3/page,11/articleid,1099_01_1977_0297_0012_16002962/|title=Da C.S. Fiat a Spa|journal=La Stampa|date=December 30, 1977|page=11|language=Italian}}</ref> and then simply as ''Sisport''.<ref name="Sisport"/> With the advent of professionalism in various sports, the club now largely caters to amateur and youth sports.
==Sports== *Athletics *Football (youth only) *Rowing *Rugby *Swimming
==Women's Basketball== {{Infobox Basketball club | color1 = | color2 = | name =Gruppo Sportivo FIAT | nickname = | logo = | imagesize = | leagues = | founded = 1922 | history = | arena = | location =[[Torino]], Italy | colors = | president = | coach = | championships ='''1''' [[Euroleague Women]] }} FIAT has won [[Euroleague Women]] in the 1979-80 season and two Italian Championships.
===Titles=== * 1 [[Euroleague Women]] (1980) * 5 Italian Championships (1962, 1963, 1964, 1979, 1980)
==Athletics== Notable former athletes include [[Mediterranean Games]] gold medalist [[Marisa Masullo]], and the four Olympic gold medalists [[Pietro Mennea]], [[Sara Simeoni]], [[Maurizio Damilano]] and [[Gabriella Dorio]] (in that period under the sponsorship of [[Fiat Iveco]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fidal.it/content/Varie-consegnato-il-premio-Aruga-a-Giampiero-Boniperti/89343|title=Varie: consegnato il premio Aruga a Giampiero Boniperti|quote=Inoltre per aver guidato alla conquista del titolo olimpico ben quattro atleti Sisport: Sara Simeoni, Maurizio Damilano, Pietro Mennea e Gabriella Dorio|publisher=fidal.it|accessdate=3 September 2017}}</ref>
===Titles=== * 1 [[European Champion Clubs Cup (athletics)#Women's|European Champion Clubs Cup]] (1993)
==Honors== *[[:it:Medaglia d'Onore al merito sportivo|Medaglia d'Onore al merito sportivo]] (Medal of Honor for Sporting Merit): 1963, 2009
==Notable athletes== *[[Alessio Boggiatto]], [[World Aquatics Championships]] gold medalist *[[Chiara Boggiatto]], swimmer and [[Mediterranean Games]] gold medalist *[[:it:Lorenzo Calafiore|Lorenzo Calafiore]], wrestler and Mediterranean Games gold medalist *[[Claudio Marchisio]], footballer for [[Juventus F.C.]] and [[Italy national football team]] (played some of his youth football at Sisport)<ref>{{cite web|author=Massimiliano Nerozzi|title=Marchisio, un fuoriclasse un normale|url=http://www.lastampa.it/2011/12/06/sport/calcio/qui-juve/marchisio-un-fuoriclasse-un-normale-VEXDNhKW6tzkPxDd9kfC0L/pagina.html|work=lastampa.it|date=December 6, 2011|language=Italian}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.sisport.life Official Website]
[[Category:Women's basketball teams in Italy]] [[Category:EuroLeague Women clubs]] [[Category:Sport in Turin]] [[Category:Basketball teams established in 1922]] [[Category:Athletics clubs in Italy]]

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Slater Family Ice Arena | nickname = | image = [[File:BGSUIce2.jpg|300px|center]] | location = [[Bowling Green State University]]
[[Bowling Green, Ohio]], United States | coordinates = {{coord|41.378958|-83.627801|type:landmark|display=inline,title|format=dms}} | broke_ground = Spring, 1965 | opened = February 25, 1967 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Bowling Green State University]] | operator = Bowling Green State University | surface = 200' x 85' (ice hockey) | construction_cost = $1.8 million | architect = Buegher & Stowe, Toledo, Ohio | former_names = BGSU Ice Arena | tenants = [[Bowling Green Falcons men's ice hockey|BGSU Men’s Ice Hockey]] (1967-present) | seating_capacity = 5,000 (ice hockey) }} The '''Slater Family Ice Arena''' is a 5,000-seat hockey arena in [[Bowling Green, Ohio]]. It is home to the [[Bowling Green Falcons men's ice hockey|BGSU Falcons ice hockey team]] of the [[Western Collegiate Hockey Association|WCHA]]. It was built from 1965 to 1967 for a cost of $1.8 million and opened in February 1967.{{cite web|author=KEVIN GORDON/Sentinel Assistant Sports Editor |url=http://www.foxtoledo.com/dpp/news/media_partners/wupw_Sentinel_Tribune_BGSU_Ice_Arena_renovations_on_hold |title=BGSU Ice Arena renovations on hold |publisher=Foxtoledo.com |date= |accessdate=2012-01-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120216171618/http://www.foxtoledo.com/dpp/news/media_partners/wupw_Sentinel_Tribune_BGSU_Ice_Arena_renovations_on_hold |archivedate=2012-02-16 |df= }} The arena originally had seating for 2,863 until 1989 when it was expanded to its current size of 5,000.{{cite web|title=BGSU Ice Arena |url=http://www2.bgsufalcons.com/sports/2009/6/25/GEN_0625093242.aspx?path=mhockey |work=[[Bowling Green Falcons|Bowling Green Athletics]] |publisher=[[Bowling Green State University|BGSU]] |accessdate=12 March 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130805231734/http://bgsufalcons.com/sports/2009/6/25/GEN_0625093242.aspx?path=mhockey |archivedate=5 August 2013 |df= }} Formerly known as the BGSU Ice Arena, it was renamed in 2016.{{cite news|last1=Kuebeck|first1=Peter|title=BGSU trustees give OK to Slater Family Ice Arena name|url=http://www.sent-trib.com/news/bgsu-trustees-give-ok-to-slater-family-ice-arena-name/article_892cff8a-be4b-11e6-b729-dfed1a4c3f82.html|accessdate=April 21, 2017|publisher=Sentinel-Tribune|date=December 9, 2016|location=[[Bowling Green, Ohio]]}} ==Ice hockey== * Bowling Green State University's [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] men's team competes in the [[Western Collegiate Hockey Association]] (WCHA). The team began in 1969 and played in the MCHA for the first two seasons before joining the CCHA as a charter member for the 1971-72 season. * BGSU men's club team ([[American Collegiate Hockey Association|ACHA]] Division II/[[Great Lakes Intercollegiate Hockey Association|GLIHA]]) * BGSU women's club team (independent) * [[Bowling Green High School (Ohio)|Bowling Green High School]] varsity and junior varsity teams * BGSU intramural [[broomball]], curling, and hockey * Bowling Green Youth Hockey Association ==Figure skating== * BGSU Synchronized Skating Team * Bowling Green Figure Skating Club * Other individual skating programs and competitions{{cite news|last=Romaker|first=Janet|title=City of Bowling Green gears up to observe A Golden Moment|url=https://www.toledoblade.com/local/2009/02/15/City-of-Bowling-Green-gears-up-to-observe-A-Golden-Moment.html|accessdate=12 March 2014|newspaper=[[The Blade (Toledo)|The Blade]]|date=15 February 2009}} ==Curling== The BGSU Ice Arena was home to the Bowling Green Curling Club for 48 years (1968-2016). In the spring of 2016, the Club began a move to a dedicated curling facility. ==External links== * [http://www.bgsufalcons.com/index.aspx?path=mhockey BGSU men's ice hockey] * [http://www.pointstreaksites.com/view/bgfalcons BGSU Men's Club Ice Hockey] * [http://www.bgsu.edu/offices/sa/recsports/ice/page36718.html BGSU Curling Club] * [http://www.bgcurlingclub.com/ Bowling Green Curling Club] * [http://www.bgyouthhockey.org/ Bowling Green Youth Hockey Association] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Bowling Green State University}} {{Bowling Green Falcons men's ice hockey navbox}} {{Western Collegiate Hockey Association men's navbox}} [[Category:Bowling Green Falcons ice hockey]] [[Category:College ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Ohio]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Ohio]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1967]] [[Category:1967 establishments in Ohio]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Wood County, Ohio]] {{Ohio-sports-venue-stub}}

revision.text:
'''Snowboard racing''' is a form of [[snowboarding]] where competitors attempt to obtain the fastest time down a course. Snowboard racing can be done against the clock, or by two or more competitors racing in a head-to-head format.
The current [[Snowboarding at the Winter Olympics|Olympic snowboarding]] racing events are [[Snowboard racing#Parallel Giant Slalom|parallel giant slalom]], [[Snowboard racing#Parallel Slalom|parallel slalom]] and [[snowboard cross]].
== Governing body == World tour events in snowboard racing are hosted by the [[Federation international du ski|FIS (Federation International De Ski).]] The FIS currently organises both a [[FIS Snowboard World Cup|world cup]] tour and a [[FIS Snowboard World Championships|world championship]] for each of the Olympic snowboard racing events (parallel giant slalom, parallel slalom and snowboard cross). The [[International Snowboard Federation]] was the former governing body.
The struggling [[International Snowboard Federation]] does not currently host a world tour in any snowboard racing format, but it is possible that it may host a tour for banked slalom in coming years.
== Events==
The major racing events are as follows:
=== Parallel giant slalom === (PGS): The '''parallel giant slalom''' event includes two evenly spaced courses (10–15 meters apart) with vertical distances of 20–27 meters between turning gates, allowing speeds up to 70 km/h. Once qualifications are complete, racers are placed in a head to head knockout format, starting with 16 athletes and moving to a final race for 1st and 2nd. It uses a much longer course than parallel slalom with gates set further apart (spaced 20–27 meters apart), resulting in even higher speeds, while racing against an opponent on a similar course place parallel to the other course. Parallel giant slalom is an Olympic event, and the FIS organises a world tour and world cup for this event.
=== Giant slalom === (GS): The original Olympic discipline for snowboard racing was '''giant slalom''', but it featured in only one Winter Olympics (Nagano 1998). It uses a much longer course than slalom, with gates set further apart (spaced 25–32 meters apart), resulting in even higher speeds. This event is still staged at Continental Cup and Regional level, but the last giant slalom world cup was held in 2000 at [https://archive.is/20130629051558/http://www.fis-ski.com/uk/604/1228.html?event_id=5835&cal_suchsector=SB Mt. Ste Anne, Quebec, Canada], with [[Jasey-Jay Anderson]] (CAN) and [[Karine Ruby]] (FRA)] winning.
=== Parallel slalom === (PSL): '''Parallel slalom''' debuted at the [[2014 Winter Olympics|Olympics in 2014 in Sochi, Russia]]. Boarders race downhill through sets of gates that force extremely tight and quick turns (spaced 8–15 meters apart), requiring plenty of technical skill while racing against an opponent in the other course.
=== Triple slalom === (TS): The '''triple slalom''' is a concept event that has been tested as a North American cup event in November 2011 at Copper Mountain. It was spearheaded by the Canadian team, as FIS had discussed it as a world cup event and possibly an Olympic format for slalom, but it had not been tested till that point. Once it was tested, it was realized it may have potential but was not the right fit for an Olympic discipline.
=== Slalom === (SL): In '''slalom''', boarders race downhill through sets of gates that force extremely tight and quick turns, (spaced 8–15 meters apart) requiring plenty of technical skill while racing against the clock. The winner of this event is based on 2 runs combined time.
=== Super-G === (SG): Boarders competing in a '''Super G''' event travel through sets of gates spaced 30–40 meters apart, requiring plenty of courage and speed while testing the endurance of the racer at speeds of up to 100 km/h. This has not been a world cup event since 1999 at [http://www.fis-ski.com/uk/604/1228.html?event_id=4330&cal_suchsector=SB Mt. Bachelor, Oregon]{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}.
=== Snowboard cross === {{further|Snowboard cross}} (SBX): In '''snowboard cross''', four snowboard racers start simultaneously atop an inclined course. The racers go over a series of features while trying to reach the finish line first. '''Snowboard cross''' became an Olympic sport in 2006.
=== Team snowboard cross === '''Team snowboard cross''' is a relatively new event. US Snowboard requested it be a part of the Winter Olympics starting in 2018. It will be confirmed in Fall 2014. --MJB 18:06, 29 June 2014 (UTC)[http://www.fis-ski.com/snowboard/freestyle-snowboard/news-multimedia/news/article=initiatives-for-new-olympic-events-move-ahead.html FIS Snowboard ].
=== Banked slalom === '''Banked slalom''' is a loosely organized group of events, primarily in the Pacific Northwest, but now seen increasingly across Western North America and the rest of the Snowboard world. Well established and iconic Banked Slalom events include Mt. Baker Banked Slalom, Neil Edgeworth Banked Slalom (NEBS) at Big White, BC and Dicks Ditch Classic (Jackson Hole, Wy). It consists of a gully run that is left largely unprepared by machines, safety fencing on the turns and in spill zones and an open relaxed format that promotes a fun spirited friendship among competitors and volunteers. It is a rite of passage to win the Baker Banked Slalom, including many of the strongest Snowboard racers and freestylers in the world including Ross Rebagliati, Terje Haakonsen and Maelle Ricker.
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{for|the American sports show|Crowd Goes Wild}} {{Refimprove|date=November 2008}} {{Infobox television | show_name = ''The Crowd Goes Wild'' | image = | caption = Crowd Goes Wild Presenters | show_name_2 = | genre = Sports | creator = | developer = | writer = | director = | creative_director = | presenter = [[Andrew Mulligan]]
[[James McOnie]] | starring = [[Andrew Mulligan]]
[[James McOnie]]
Chris Key
Huw Beynon
[[Josh Kronfeld]]
[[Cat Tuivaiti]]
[[Wairangi Koopu]]
[[Anna Willcox-Silfverberg]]
[[Storm Purvis]] | judges = | voices = | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = | country = [[New Zealand]] | language = [[New Zealand English]] | num_seasons = 12 (2006-2018) | num_episodes = | list_episodes = | producer = Huw Beynon
James Copland | executive_producer = [[Ric Salizzo]] | editor = Logan Swinkels
James Copland | location = | cinematography = Logan Swinkels
James Copland
Nathan McKinnon | camera = [[Multi-camera]] | runtime = 30 minutes | company = | distributor = [[Sky Network Television]] | channel = [[Prime (New Zealand)|Prime TV]] | picture_format = [[HDTV]] [[1080i]] | audio_format = | first_run = | first_aired = Monday 26 June 2006 | last_aired = present | preceded_by = | related = | website = http://www.primetv.co.nz/Default.aspx?tabid=93&art_id=47 | website_title = Prime TV – The Crowd Goes Wild | production_website = http://www.primetv.co.nz/ }} '''''The Crowd Goes Wild''''' is a 30-minute sports entertainment show broadcast on [[New Zealand]] nationwide television channel [[Prime (New Zealand)|Prime TV]].[http://www.primetv.co.nz/default.asp?a=7&t=7&View=FullStory&newsID=1 Prime TV - The Crowd Goes Wild] The show premiered on Monday 26 June 2006.[http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/CU0606/S00099.htm The Crowd Goes Wild - Weekdays at 7pm on Prime] ''Scoop NZ Website'', 13 June 2006 ''The Crowd Goes Wild'' is presented by sports journalist [[Andrew Mulligan]] and [[James McOnie]], [[Hayley Holt]], [[Ric Salizzo]], [[Wairangi Koopu]], Chris Key or Huw Beynon if either of the main hosts are away. The programme covers the sporting events of the day in a lighthearted format, broadcast live from the studio with pre-recorded segments and clips. It airs five times per week at 7:00pm on weeknights and is replayed on both Prime and Sky Sports .[http://www.primetv.co.nz/Default.aspx?tabid=93&art_id=47 The Crowd Goes Wild] ''Prime TV'' In late 2010 the show was moved from its live 7pm timeslot to 10:30pm, with the show being recorded at 6:30pm (and played at that time on Sky Sport 1). This move was unpopular, criticised by at least one commentator, and ultimately reversed.[http://www.stuff.co.nz/entertainment/blogs/on-the-box/4297067/An-open-letter-to-The-Crowd-Goes-Wild Philpott, Chris: 'An open letter to The Crowd Goes Wild' Stuff.co.nz, 2/11/2010] Field reporters include James McOnie, [[Hayley Holt]], Chris Key, Makere Gibbons, former All Black [[Josh Kronfeld]], former [[Silver Fern]] [[Cat Tuivaiti]], Rugby League star [[Wairangi Koopu]], Winter Olympic athlete [[Anna Willcox-Silfverberg]], and former [[Silver Fern]] [[Storm Purvis]] . [http://www.skytv.co.nz/Default.aspx?tabid=616&art_id=19139 The Crowd Goes Wild Interview with James and James] ''SkyWatch''[http://www.primetv.co.nz/Default.aspx?tabid=93&art_id=47 The Crowd Goes Wild Friday] ''Prime TV'' Former [[Sports Cafe]] host and veteran journalist [[Ric Salizzo]] is the show's executive producer, who also on rare occasions will host as well. ==Presenters and reporters== *[[Andrew Mulligan]] – presenter *[[James McOnie]] – presenter *[[Josh Kronfeld]] – reporter *[[Wairangi Koopu]] – reporter *Chris Key – reporter *James Copland – producer *Huw Beynon – producer, reporter & presenter[https://nz.linkedin.com/in/huw-beynon-4586b16b Huw Beynon] LinkedIn *Makere Gibbons – reporter *[[Anna Willcox-Silfverberg]] – reporter *[[Storm Purvis]] – reporter[https://nz.linkedin.com/in/storm-purvis-83156ba8 Storm Purvis] LinkedIn ==Former presenters and reporters== *[[James Somerset]] – reporter – Feb 2008 to Nov 2013 *[[Mark Richardson (cricketer)|Mark Richardson]] – presenter – Feb 2006 to Dec 2016 *[[Hayley Holt]] – reporter – Dec 2009 to Jan 2018 ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Crowd Goes Wild}} [[Category:Prime (New Zealand) programmes]] [[Category:2000s New Zealand television series]] [[Category:2006 New Zealand television series debuts]] [[Category:2010s New Zealand television series]] [[Category:New Zealand sports television series]] {{Sport-tv-prog-stub}} {{NewZealand-sport-stub}} {{NewZealand-tv-stub}}
